<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Indicate by check mark whether the registrants (1)&nbsp;have filed all reports required to be filed by Section&nbsp;13 or 15(d) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 during the preceding 12 months (or for such shorter period that the registrants were required to file such reports) and (2)&nbsp;have been subject to such filing requirements for the past 90&nbsp;days. Yes&nbsp;</font><font color=#000000><font face="Wingdings 2">&#083;</font></font><font color=#000000>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;No&nbsp;</font><font color=#000000><font face="Wingdings 2">&#163;</font></font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of October 24, 2005, Public Service Enterprise Group Incorporated had outstanding 239,296,281 shares of its sole class of Common Stock, without par value.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of October&nbsp;24, 2005, Public Service Electric and Gas Company had issued and outstanding 132,450,344 shares of Common Stock, without nominal or par value, all of which were privately held, beneficially and of record by Public Service Enterprise Group Incorporated.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG Power LLC and PSEG Energy Holdings L.L.C. are wholly owned subsidiaries of Public Service Enterprise Group Incorporated and meet the conditions set forth in General Instruction H(1) (a) and (b) of Form&nbsp;10-Q and are filing their respective Quarterly Reports on Form&nbsp;10-Q with the reduced disclosure format authorized by General Instruction&nbsp;H.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Indicate by check mark whether each registrant is an accelerated filer (as defined in Rule&nbsp;12b-2 of the Exchange Act).</font></p>

<p align=center><b><font color=#000000><a name='Forward'>FORWARD-LOOKING STATEMENTS</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Certain of the matters discussed in this report constitute &ldquo;forward-looking statements&rdquo; within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Such forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties, which could cause actual results to differ materially from those anticipated. Such statements are based on management&#39;s beliefs as well as assumptions made by and information currently available to management. When used herein, the words &ldquo;anticipate,&rdquo; &ldquo;intend,&rdquo; &ldquo;estimate,&rdquo; &ldquo;believe,&rdquo; &ldquo;expect,&rdquo; &ldquo;plan,&rdquo; &ldquo;hypothetical,&rdquo; &ldquo;potential,&rdquo; &ldquo;forecast,&rdquo; &ldquo;project,&rdquo; variations of such words and similar expressions are intended to identify forward-looking statements. Public
Service Enterprise Group Incorporated (PSEG), Public Service Electric and Gas Company (PSE&amp;G), PSEG Power LLC (Power) and PSEG Energy Holdings L.L.C. (Energy Holdings) undertake no obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. The following review should not be construed as a complete list of factors that could effect forward-looking statements.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In addition to any assumptions and other factors referred to specifically in connection with such forward-looking statements discussed above, factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those contemplated in any forward-looking statements include, among others, the following:</font></p>

Undue reliance should not be placed on these forward-looking statements in making any investment decision. Each of PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings expressly disclaims any obligation or undertaking to release publicly any updates or revisions to these forward-looking statements to reflect events or circumstances that occur or arise or are anticipated to occur
or arise after the date hereof. In making any investment decision regarding PSEG&#39;s, PSE&amp;G&#39;s, Power&#39;s and Energy Holdings&#39; securities, PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings are not making, and you should not infer, any representation about the likely existence of any particular future set of facts or circumstances. The forward-looking statements contained in this report are intended to qualify for the safe harbor provisions of Section&nbsp;27A of the Securities Act of 1933, as amended, and Section&nbsp;21E of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended.</font></p>

<p align=center><b><font color=#000000><a name='Public1'>PUBLIC SERVICE ELECTRIC AND GAS COMPANY</a><br>
</font><font color=#000000>CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED STATEMENTS OF OPERATIONS</font></b></p>
<table width=100% cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0><tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>

September 30,<br>
<hr color=#000000 noshade size=1></small></font></b></td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=center valign=bottom colspan=7><b><font color=#000000><small>For The Nine Months Ended<br>
September 30,<br>
<hr color=#000000 noshade size=1></small></font></b></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=center valign=bottom colspan=3><b><font color=#000000><small>2005<br>
<hr color=#000000 noshade size=1></small></font></b></td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=center valign=bottom colspan=3><b><font color=#000000><small>2004<br>

<td align=center valign=bottom colspan=3><b><font color=#000000><small>2004<br>
<hr color=#000000 noshade size=1></small></font></b></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=center valign=top colspan=15><b><font color=#000000><small>(Millions)<br>
(Unaudited)</small></font></b></td></tr>

<tr bgcolor=#e5ffff>

<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#e5ffff>
<td align=left valign=bottom><p style='margin-left:3em;text-indent:-1em;'><font color=#000000>Adjustments to Reconcile Net Income to Net Cash Flows from<br>
Operating Activities:</font></p></td>

included in the Notes to Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements.</font></p>

<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000><a name='Notes'>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS</a><br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>This combined Form&nbsp;10-Q is separately filed by Public Service Enterprise Group Incorporated (PSEG), Public Service Electric and Gas Company (PSE&amp;G), PSEG Power LLC (Power) and PSEG Energy Holdings L.L.C. (Energy Holdings). Information contained herein relating to any individual company is filed by such company on its own behalf. PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings each make representations only as to itself and make no representations as to any other company.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Note1'>Note 1. Organization and Basis of Presentation</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Organization</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG has four principal direct wholly owned subsidiaries: PSE&amp;G, Power, Energy Holdings and PSEG Services Corporation (Services).</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As previously disclosed, on December 20, 2004, PSEG entered into an agreement and plan of merger (Merger Agreement) with Exelon Corporation (Exelon), a public utility holding company registered under the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 (PUHCA), which is headquartered in Chicago, Illinois, whereby PSEG will be merged with and into Exelon (Merger). Under the Merger Agreement, each share of PSEG Common Stock will be converted into 1.225 shares of Exelon Common Stock.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The Merger Agreement has been unanimously approved by both companies&#39; Boards of Directors. On June&nbsp;30, 2005, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) approved the Merger. On July&nbsp;19, 2005, shareholders of PSEG voted to approve the Merger and on July&nbsp;22, 2005, shareholders of Exelon voted to approve the issuance of common shares to PSEG shareholders to effect the Merger.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Completion of the Merger is subject to approval by a number of governmental authorities, some of which have already been obtained. The authorities may impose conditions on completion of the Merger, require changes to the terms of the Merger or fail to approve the Merger.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G is an operating public utility engaged principally in the transmission of electric energy and distribution of electric energy and natural gas service in certain areas of New Jersey. PSE&amp;G is subject to regulation by the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities (BPU) and the FERC.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G also owns PSE&amp;G Transition Funding LLC (Transition Funding) and PSE&amp;G Transition Funding&nbsp;II LLC (Transition Funding&nbsp;II), bankruptcy-remote entities that purchased certain transition property from PSE&amp;G and issued transition bonds secured by such property. The transition property consists principally of the right to receive electricity consumption-based per kilowatt hour charges from PSE&amp;G electric distribution customers, which represents the irrevocable right to receive amounts sufficient to recover certain of PSE&amp;G&#39;s transition costs related to deregulation, as approved by the BPU.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power is a multi-regional, wholesale energy supply company that integrates its generating asset operations with its wholesale energy, fuel supply, energy trading and marketing and risk management function through three principal direct wholly owned subsidiaries: PSEG Nuclear LLC (Nuclear), PSEG Fossil LLC (Fossil) and PSEG Energy Resources&nbsp;&amp; Trade LLC (ER&amp;T). Nuclear and Fossil own and operate generation and generation-related facilities. ER&amp;T is responsible for the&nbsp;day-to-day management of the portfolio. Fossil, Nuclear and ER&amp;T are subject to regulation by the FERC and Nuclear is subject to regulation by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC).</font></p>
<p align=center>16</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Energy Holdings
  has two principal direct wholly owned subsidiaries: PSEG Global L.L.C. (Global),
  which owns and operates international and domestic projects engaged in the generation
  and distribution of energy, including power production facilities and electric
  distribution companies and PSEG Resources L.L.C. (Resources), which has primarily
  invested in energy-related leveraged leases. Energy Holdings also owns Enterprise
  Group Development Corporation (EGDC), a commercial real estate property management
  business.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Services</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Services provides management and administrative services to PSEG and its subsidiaries. These include accounting, legal, communications, human resources, information technology, treasury and financial services, investor relations, stockholder services, real estate, environmental, health and safety, insurance, risk management, tax, library, records and information services, security, corporate secretarial and certain planning, budgeting and forecasting services. Services charges PSEG and its subsidiaries for the cost of work performed and services provided pursuant to the terms and conditions of intercompany service agreements.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Basis of Presentation</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The respective financial statements included herein have been prepared pursuant to the rules and regulations of the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) for Quarterly Reports on Form&nbsp;10-Q. Certain information and note disclosures normally included in financial statements prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States (GAAP) have been condensed or omitted pursuant to such rules and regulations. These Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements and Notes to Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements (Notes) should be read in conjunction with and update and supplement matters discussed in PSEG&#39;s, PSE&amp;G&#39;s, Power&#39;s and Energy Holdings&#39; respective Annual Reports on Form&nbsp;10-K for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2004 and Quarterly Reports on Form&nbsp;10-Q
for the quarters ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 and June&nbsp;30, 2005.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The unaudited condensed consolidated financial information furnished herein reflects all adjustments&nbsp;which are, in the opinion of management, necessary to fairly state the results for the interim periods presented. All such adjustments are of a normal recurring nature. The year-end Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheets were derived from the audited Consolidated Financial Statements included in the Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2004. Certain reclassifications of prior period data have been made to conform with the current presentation.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Pension and Other Postretirement Benefits (OPEB)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG sponsors several qualified and nonqualified pension plans and OPEB plans covering PSEG and its participating affiliates&#39; current and former employees who meet certain eligibility criteria. As a result of union negotiations, certain changes to the pension plans and OPEB plans were made and communicated in March 2005. These include increases to the benefit formula in the pension plan, supplemental pension benefits and certain other changes to OPEB. Substantially all changes to the pension plans became effective May&nbsp;1, 2005 and the majority of changes to the OPEB plans will be effective January&nbsp;1, 2006 or July&nbsp;1, 2006. The pension benefits and OPEB obligations, as well as the asset values, have been re-measured as of March&nbsp;31, 2005 to reflect the effect of the plan changes. With these assumption
changes and based on a discount rate of 6.0%, the new pension projected benefit obligation and accumulated benefit obligation as of March&nbsp;31, 2005 were $3.5 billion and $2.9 billion, respectively. The new OPEB accumulated benefit obligation as of March&nbsp;31, 2005 was $1.1 billion. The</font></p>
<p align=center>17</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>annual net periodic pension benefit costs for 2005 increase by approximately $2 million or 2% and the 2005 annual net OPEB costs increase by approximately $11 million or 11% from costs that would have been expensed in 2005 had the plans&#39; provisions remained unchanged.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The following table provides the components of net periodic benefit costs relating to all qualified and nonqualified pension plans and OPEB plans on an aggregate basis:</font></p>

<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Stock Compensation</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG applies Accounting Principles Board (APB) Opinion No. 25, &ldquo;Accounting for Stock Issued to Employees&rdquo; (APB&nbsp;25) and related interpretations in accounting for stock-based compensation plans. Accordingly, no compensation cost has been recognized for fixed stock option grants since the exercise price of the stock options equaled the market price of the underlying stock on the date of grant.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG also grants restricted stock and performance units to certain key executives and employees. In 2005, 270,000 shares of restricted stock have been granted under the 2004 Long-Term Incentive Plan to certain key executives and employees. These shares vest on a staggered schedule beginning in January 2006 and become fully vested in January 2008, except for accelerated vesting in the case of retirement or involuntary separation without cause. Compensation expense on the restricted stock grants is recorded ratably over the vesting period. Compensation expense for performance units is measured and recognized once it can be determined that the performance goals will be achieved.</font></p>
<p align=center>18</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>See Note 4. Earnings Per Share for further information.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a Name='Note2'>Note 2. Recent Accounting Standards</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>SFAS No. 154, &ldquo;Accounting Changes and Error Corrections&rdquo; (SFAS 154)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In May 2005, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) issued SFAS&nbsp; 154, which is effective for accounting changes and corrections of errors made in fiscal years beginning after December&nbsp;15, 2005. SFAS&nbsp;154 requires retrospective application to prior periods&#39; financial statements of voluntary changes in accounting principles unless it is impracticable to determine either the period-specific effects or the cumulative effect of the change.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>SFAS 154
  requires that a change in depreciation, amortization or depletion method for
  long-lived non-financial assets be accounted for as a change in accounting estimate
  effected by a change in accounting principle. The adoption of SFAS&nbsp;154
  is not expected to have a material effect on PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power or Energy
  Holdings.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>SFAS No. 123 (revised 2004), &ldquo;Share-Based Payment&rdquo; (SFAS 123R)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In December 2004, the FASB issued SFAS 123R, which revises SFAS&nbsp;123 and supersedes APB 25 and its related implementation guidance. SFAS&nbsp;123R focuses primarily on accounting for transactions in which an entity obtains employee services in share-based payment transactions. SFAS&nbsp;123R is effective for the first annual reporting period beginning after June&nbsp;15, 2005 and requires entities to recognize stock compensation expense for awards of equity instruments to employees based on the grant-date fair value of those awards (with limited exceptions). Adoption of SFAS&nbsp;123R is not expected to have a material effect on PSEG&#39;s financial statements.</font></p>
<p align=center>19</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>FASB Interpretation No. (FIN) 47, &ldquo;Accounting for Conditional Asset Retirement Obligations&rdquo; (FIN 47)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In March 2005, the FASB issued FIN 47 to clarify the term &ldquo;conditional asset retirement obligation&rdquo; as used in SFAS No.&nbsp;143, &ldquo;Accounting for Asset Retirement Obligations.&rdquo; Conditional asset retirement obligation refers to a legal obligation to perform an asset retirement activity in which the timing and/or method of settlement are conditional on a future event that may or may not be within the control of the entity. The obligation to perform the asset retirement activity is unconditional even though uncertainty exists about the timing and/or method of settlement. Accordingly, an entity is required to recognize a liability for the fair value of a conditional asset retirement obligation if the fair value of the liability can be reasonably estimated. The fair value of a liability for the conditional
asset retirement obligation should be recognized when incurred - generally, upon acquisition, construction, development and/or through the normal operation of the asset. Uncertainty about the timing and/or method of settlement should be factored into the measurement of the liability when sufficient information exists. FIN&nbsp;47 also clarifies when an entity would have sufficient information to reasonably estimate the fair value of an asset retirement obligation. FIN&nbsp;47 is effective no later than the end of fiscal years ending after December&nbsp;15, 2005. PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings are currently evaluating the impact that adoption of FIN&nbsp;47 may have on their respective financial statements.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>FSP No.&nbsp;109-1, &ldquo;Application of FASB Statement No.&nbsp;109, &ldquo;</font></b><i><b><font color=#000000>Accounting for Income Taxes</font></b></i><b><font color=#000000>&rdquo;, to the Tax Deduction on Qualified Production Activities Provided by the American Jobs Creation Act of 2004&rdquo; (FSP&nbsp;109-1)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On December 21, 2004, the FASB issued FSP&nbsp;109-1, which was effective upon issuance, to provide guidance on the application of SFAS No. 109, &ldquo;Accounting for Income Taxes&rdquo; (SFAS&nbsp;109), to the provision within the American Jobs Creation Act of 2004 (Jobs Act) that provides a tax deduction on qualified production activities. The Jobs Act includes a tax deduction of up to 9% (when fully phased-in) of the lesser of (a)&nbsp;&ldquo;qualified production activities income,&rdquo; as defined in the Jobs Act, or (b)&nbsp;taxable income (after the deduction for the utilization of any net operating loss carryforwards). The tax deduction is limited to 50% of&nbsp;W-2 wages paid by the taxpayer. FSP&nbsp;109-1 clarifies that the manufacturer&#39;s deduction provided for under the Jobs Act should be accounted for as
a special deduction in accordance with SFAS 109 and not as a tax rate reduction. PSEG, Power and Energy Holdings do not believe that the manufacturer&#39;s deduction or the application of FSP&nbsp;109-1 will have a material effect on their respective financial statements.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>FSP No.&nbsp;109-2, &ldquo;Accounting and Disclosure Guidance for the Foreign Earnings Repatriation Provision within the American Jobs Creation Act of 2004&rdquo; (FSP&nbsp;109-2)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On December 21, 2004, the FASB issued FSP&nbsp;109-2, which was effective upon issuance, to provide guidance on the application of the provision in the Jobs Act that allows a special one-time dividends received deduction on the repatriation of certain foreign earnings to a U.S. taxpayer, provided certain criteria are met. The Jobs Act provides a one-year window to repatriate earnings from foreign investments and claim a special 85% dividends received tax deduction on such distributions.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG has approved Domestic Reinvestment Plans, which provided for the repatriation of approximately $182 million through October 2005, of which approximately $140 million was eligible for the reduced tax rate pursuant to the Jobs Act. The tax expense associated with such repatriation totaled approximately $9 million and was recorded in the quarter ended September 30, 2005. In addition, Global&#39;s projections indicate that additional earnings could be generated by its international investments over the balance of 2005 that could increase the amount of funds that could reasonably be</font></p>
<p align=center>20</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>considered for repatriation in 2005 by approximately $50 million, which would result in an additional $2 million of tax expense. Other than amounts discussed above, Global has made no change in its current intention to indefinitely reinvest accumulated earnings of its foreign subsidiaries.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Proposed Standards</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In July 2005, the FASB issued proposed guidance concerning the accounting for uncertain tax positions and the accounting for the timing of cash flows relating to income taxes generated by leveraged lease transactions.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The proposal concerning uncertain tax positions would require that an uncertain tax position meet a probable recognition threshold based on the merits of the position in order for the benefit to be recognized in the financial statements. The proposal also addresses the accrual of interest and penalties related to tax uncertainties and the classification of liabilities on the balance sheet. If implemented in its present form, the impact of this proposal on PSEG and Energy Holdings could be material.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The proposal concerning leveraged leases would require a lessor to perform a recalculation of a leveraged lease when there is a change in the timing of the realization of tax benefits generated by the lease. It would also require a lessor to re-evaluate classification as a leveraged lease when a recalculation of the lease is performed. If implemented in its present form, the impact of this proposal on PSEG and Energy Holdings could be material.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Note3'>Note 3. Discontinued Operations, Dispositions and Acquisitions</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Discontinued Operations</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Waterford Generation Facility (Waterford)</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On May 27, 2005, Power entered into an agreement to sell its electric generation facility located in Waterford, Ohio to a subsidiary of American Electric Power Company, Inc. Since commencing construction of the project, the dramatic increase in natural gas prices relative to the price increase of coal and the failure to receive capacity compensation for the facility caused Power to consider alternatives for the project. After reviewing the alternatives in conjunction with other strategic and financial considerations, Power concluded that the value to be received from the sale of Waterford represented a means to accelerate the realization of the plant&#39;s value. The sale price for the facility and inventory was $220 million.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>During 2005, Power recognized a loss on disposal of $178 million, net of tax. Power completed the sale of Waterford on September&nbsp;28, 2005. The proceeds of the sale, together with an anticipated reduction in tax liability, are approximately $320 million, which will be used to retire debt at Power.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Waterford&#39;s operating results for the quarters and nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2005 and 2004 are summarized below:</font></p>

<td align=left valign=bottom><p style='margin-left:1em;text-indent:-1em;'><font color=#000000>Loss Before Income Taxes</font></p></td>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Carthage Power Company (CPC)</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In December 2003, Global entered into a definitive purchase and sale agreement related to the sale of its majority interest in CPC, which owns and operates a power plant located in Rades, Tunisia. In December 2003, Global also recognized an estimated loss on disposal of $23 million for the initial write-down of its carrying amount of CPC to its fair value less cost to sell. During the first quarter of 2004, Energy Holdings re-evaluated the carrying value of CPC&#39;s assets and liabilities and determined that an additional write-down to fair value of $2 million was required, which offset CPC&#39;s Net Income for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2004. In May 2004, Global completed the sale of CPC for approximately $43 million in cash and recognized a gain on disposal of $5 million.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The operating results of CPC for the nine months ended September 30, 2004 are summarized below:</font></p>
<table width=100% cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0><tr bgcolor=#ffffff>

September&nbsp;30, 2004<br>
<hr color=#000000 noshade size=1></small></font></b></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>

<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Dispositions</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Meiya Power Company Limited (MPC)</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In December 2004, Global closed on the sale of its 50% equity interest in MPC to BTU Power Company for approximately $236 million, of which $100 million was paid in cash. The balance of approximately $136 million was provided in the form of a secured promissory note due on March&nbsp;31, 2005, which was later amended to extend the maturity date to April 2005 and increase the amount due. The sale resulted in an after-tax gain of approximately $2 million, which was recorded in the fourth quarter of 2004. Global received payments of $38 million and $99 million in January 2005 and April 2005, respectively, representing the full payment of the outstanding receivable.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Luz Del Sur S.A.A. (LDS)</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In April 2004, Global sold a portion of its indirect ownership in LDS in the Lima stock exchange, reducing its ownership from 44% to 38% and received gross proceeds of approximately $31 million. Global realized an after-tax gain of approximately $5 million in the second quarter of 2004 related to the LDS sale which is recorded in Income from Equity Method Investments on the Condensed Consolidated Statements of Operations.</font></p>
<p align=center>22</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Solar Electric Generating Systems (SEGS) Projects</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In January 2005, Resources and Global sold their minority limited partner interests in three SEGS projects for proceeds of approximately $7 million resulting in an after-tax gain of $4 million.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Dhofar Power Company S.A.O.C. (Dhofar Power)</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In April 2005, Global sold a 35% interest in Dhofar Power through a public offering on the Omani stock exchange as required under the Concession Agreement, reducing Global&#39;s ownership in Dhofar Power from 81% to 46%. Net proceeds from the sale approximated $25 million, resulting in a modest gain. As a result, Global&#39;s investment in Dhofar Power has been accounted for under the equity method following the sale. Global&#39;s investment in Dhofar Power was $20 million and $53 million as of September&nbsp;30, 2005 and December&nbsp;31, 2004, respectively.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Resources</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Resources was the lessor of a Boeing B767 to United Airlines (UAL). In December 2002, UAL filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. On June&nbsp;13, 2005, Resources received a notice from the Trustee under the UAL lease that the lenders had terminated the lease and repossessed the aircraft. Upon receipt of this notice, Resources recorded a $15 million charge, after-tax, in June 2005 to eliminate its carrying value of this investment since management believes that there will be insufficient proceeds to recover any of the recorded amount of the investment due to the termination.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In January 2005, the KKR Fund sold its investment in KinderCare Learning Centers, Inc. and Resources received proceeds of approximately $17 million resulting in an after-tax gain of approximately $1 million.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In March 2004, Resources entered into an agreement with Midwest Generation LLC, an indirect subsidiary of Edison Mission Energy, to terminate its lease investment in the Collins generating facility in Illinois. In March 2004, Resources recorded a $17 million&nbsp;pre-tax charge to reduce its carrying value of the Collins Lease. In April 2004, Resources closed on the termination of the lease agreement and received gross proceeds of approximately $184 million. The actual loss on the termination of the lease was $11 million, after-tax. As a result of the sale, Resources paid approximately $100 million in taxes.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In January 2004, Resources terminated two lease transactions with Qantas Airways and China Eastern Airlines Co., Ltd resulting from the lessees exercising their respective purchase options. Resources received aggregate gross cash proceeds of approximately $45 million and recorded an after-tax gain of $4 million. As a result of the sale, Resources paid approximately $36 million in taxes.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Acquisitions</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Texas Independent Energy, L.P. (TIE)</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In July 2004, Global signed an agreement to acquire all of TECO Energy, Inc.&#39;s 50% equity interest in TIE for less than $1 million. With this purchase, Global owns 100% of TIE and consolidated this investment beginning July&nbsp;1, 2004.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Energy Holdings&#39; consolidated Operating Revenues for the nine months ended September 30, 2004 would have increased from $701 million to $961 million had the acquisition of TIE occurred at the beginning of 2004. Energy Holdings&#39; consolidated Net Income for the nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2004 would have increased from $110 million to $112 million had the acquisition of TIE occurred at the beginning of 2004. This pro forma information is presented for informational purposes only and is not necessarily indicative of the results of operations that actually would have been achieved had the acquisition been consummated as of that time, nor is it intended to be a projection of future results.</font></p>
<p align=center>23</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Note4'>Note 4. Earnings Per Share (EPS)</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Diluted EPS is calculated by dividing Net Income by the weighted average number of shares of common stock outstanding, including shares issuable upon exercise of stock options outstanding under PSEG&rsquo;s stock option plans, upon payment of performance units and upon conversion of Participating Units. The following table shows the effect of these stock options, performance units and Participating Units on the weighted average number of shares outstanding used in calculating diluted EPS:</font></p>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>There were approximately 5.3 million and 2.9 million stock options excluded from the weighted average common shares calculation used for diluted EPS due to their antidilutive effect for the quarter and nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2004, respectively. No stock options had an antidilutive effect for the quarter and nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2005.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Dividend payments on common stock for the quarters ended September&nbsp;30, 2005 and 2004 were $0.56 and $0.55 per share, respectively, and totaled approximately $134 million and $131 million, respectively. Dividend payments on common stock for the nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2005 and 2004 were $1.68 and $1.65 per share, respectively, and totaled approximately $401 million and $391 million, respectively.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Note5'>Note 5. Commitments and Contingent Liabilities</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Guaranteed Obligations</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power has unconditionally guaranteed payments by its subsidiary, ER&amp;T, in certain commodity-related transactions in the ordinary course of business. These payment guarantees were provided to counterparties in order to obtain credit under physical and financial agreements for gas, pipeline capacity, transportation, oil, electricity and related commodities and services. These Power payment guarantees support the current exposure, interest and other costs on sums due and payable by ER&amp;T under these agreements. Guarantees offered for trading and marketing cover lines of credit between entities and are often reciprocal in nature. The exposure between counterparties can move in either direction. The face value of the guarantees outstanding as of September&nbsp;30, 2005 and December&nbsp;31, 2004 was $1.7 billion and $1.6
billion, respectively. In order for Power to incur a liability for the face value of the outstanding guarantees, ER&amp;T would have to fully utilize the credit granted to it by every</font></p>
<p align=center>24</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>counterparty to whom Power has provided a guarantee and all of ER&amp;T&rsquo;s contracts would have to be &ldquo;out-of-the-money&rdquo; (if the contracts are terminated, Power would owe money to the counterparties). The probability of all contracts at ER&amp;T being simultaneously &ldquo;out-of-the-money&rdquo; is highly unlikely. For this reason, the current exposure at any point in time is a more meaningful representation of the potential liability to Power under these guarantees. The current exposure consists of the net of accounts receivable and accounts payable and the forward value on open positions, less any margins posted. The current exposure from such liabilities was $687 million and $507 million as of September&nbsp;30, 2005 and December&nbsp;31, 2004, respectively.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power is subject to collateral calls related to commodity contracts that are bilateral and is subject to certain creditworthiness standards as guarantor under performance guarantees for ER&amp;T&rsquo;s agreements. There has been a significant increase in commodity prices, including fuel, emission allowances and electric. Over the last year, both natural gas prices and electric prices in PJM have more than doubled. These price increases can have an impact on contract terms and conditions, as margin calls on contracts entered into in the normal course of business will increase with price increases. As of September&nbsp;30, 2005, Power had paid cash margin of approximately $251 million and received cash margin of approximately $99 million. In addition, as of September&nbsp;30, 2005, letters of credit issued by Power were
outstanding in the amount of approximately $705 million (including $205 million issued to PSE&amp;G) to satisfy trading collateral obligations and support various contractual and environmental obligations. Assuming no changes in energy prices and positions, Power&rsquo;s collateral requirements can be expected to decline over time as its contracts expire. In the event of a deterioration of Power&rsquo;s credit rating to below investment grade, many of these agreements allow the counterparty to demand that ER&amp;T provide further performance assurance, generally in the form of a letter of credit or cash. As of September&nbsp;30, 2005, if Power were to lose its investment grade rating and, assuming all counterparties to which ER&amp;T is &ldquo;out-of-the-money&rdquo; were contractually entitled to demand, and demanded, performance assurance, ER&amp;T could be required to post additional collateral
in an amount equal to approximately $1.2 billion. PSEG and Power entered into additional credit agreements in October 2005 increasing available liquidity by $500 million. Power believes that it has sufficient access to liquidity to post such collateral, as may be necessary.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Energy Holdings and/or Global have guaranteed certain obligations of their subsidiaries or affiliates, including the successful completion, performance or other obligations related to certain projects.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The contingent obligations as of September&nbsp;30, 2005 and December&nbsp;31, 2004 are as follows:</font></p>
