<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><i><font color=#000000>(footnote continued from previous page)</font></i></p>
<table width=100% cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0><tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top><p style='margin-left:1em;text-indent:-1em;'><font color=#000000>(B)</font></p></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>PSEG&#39;s other activities include amounts applicable to PSEG (as parent corporation), and intercompany eliminations, primarily relating to intercompany transactions between Power and PSE&amp;G. No gains or losses are recorded on any intercompany transactions; rather, all intercompany transactions are at cost or, in the case of the BGS and BGSS contracts between Power and PSE&amp;G, at rates prescribed by the BPU. For a further discussion of the intercompany transactions between Power and PSE&amp;G, see Note&nbsp;12. Related-Party Transactions. The net losses primarily relate to financing and certain administrative and general costs at PSEG, as parent corporation.</font></td></tr>
</table>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Note12'>Note 12. Related-Party Transactions</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The majority of the following discussion relates to intercompany transactions, which are eliminated during the PSEG consolidation process.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>BGSS and BGS Contracts</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G and Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G has entered into a requirements contract with Power under which Power provides the gas supply services needed to meet PSE&amp;G&#39;s BGSS and other contractual requirements through March 2007.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power has also entered into contracts to supply energy, capacity and ancillary services to PSE&amp;G through the BGS auction process.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The amounts which Power charged to PSE&amp;G for BGS and BGSS are presented below:</font></p>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of September 30, 2005 and December 31, 2004, Power had net receivables from PSE&amp;G of approximately $125 million and $357 million, respectively, primarily related to the BGS and BGSS contracts. These transactions were properly recognized on each company&#39;s stand-alone financial statements.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In addition, as of September 30, 2005 and December&nbsp;31, 2004, PSE&amp;G had a receivable from Power of approximately $462 million and $25 million, respectively, related to gas supply hedges Power entered into for BGSS. For additional information, see Note&nbsp;5. Commitments and Contingent Liabilities.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Services</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Services provides and bills administrative services to PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings. In addition, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings have other payables to Services, including amounts related to certain common costs, such as pension and OPEB costs, which Services pays on behalf of</font></p>

PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings each believes that the costs of services provided by Services approximates market value for such services.</font></p>

<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Affiliate Loans and Advances</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG and Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of September 30, 2005, Power had a note receivable due from PSEG of approximately $62 million, reflecting the investment of its excess cash with PSEG. As of December&nbsp;31, 2004, Power had a payable to PSEG of approximately $98 million for short-term funding needs. Interest Income and Interest Expense relating to these short-term funding activities was immaterial.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of September 30, 2005 and December 31, 2004, Energy Holdings had a note receivable due from PSEG of approximately $61 million and $115 million, respectively, reflecting the investment of its excess cash with PSEG. Interest Income related to these borrowings was immaterial.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G and Services</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of September 30, 2005 and December 31, 2004, PSE&amp;G had advanced working capital to Services of approximately $33 million. This amount is included in Other Noncurrent Assets on PSE&amp;G&#39;s Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheets.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power and Services</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of September 30, 2005 and December 31, 2004, Power had advanced working capital to Services of approximately $17 million. This amount is included in Other Noncurrent Assets on Power&#39;s Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheets.</font></p>
<p align=center>47</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Other</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG and PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of September 30, 2005 and December 31, 2004, PSE&amp;G had receivables from PSEG of approximately $8 million and $14 million, respectively, related to amounts that PSEG had collected on PSE&amp;G&#39;s behalf.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG and Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of September 30, 2005 and December 31, 2004, Power had receivables from PSEG of approximately $4 million related to amounts that PSEG had collected on Power&#39;s behalf.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of September&nbsp;30, 2005 and December&nbsp;31, 2004, Global had loans of approximately $60 million and $68 million, respectively, due from Prisma, a joint venture which is 50%-owned by Global and operates several biomass generation plants in Italy. The decrease in the loan balances, which are denominated in Euros, was due to the strengthening of the U.S. dollar relative to the Euro during the first nine months of 2005 and was recorded as a foreign currency loss in Other Deductions. Included in the loan balances as of September&nbsp;30, 2005 and December&nbsp;31, 2004 was $24 million of accrued interest. These loans are guaranteed by an affiliate of Global&rsquo;s partner. Due to insufficient funds at the project level, total payments of $8 million due to Global on June 30, 2005 and September&nbsp;30, 2005 were not
made. In August 2005, Global began seeking to enforce its rights under the guarantee as it continues to attempt to negotiate a restructuring of the Prisma project with its partner.</font></p>
<p align=center>48</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>

<p align=center>51</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000><a name='Management'></font></b></p>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>ITEM 2. MANAGEMENT&rsquo;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL<br>
CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS (MD&amp;A)</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Following are the significant changes in or additions to information reported in the 2004 Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K affecting the consolidated financial condition and the results of operations. This discussion refers to the Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements (Statements) and the related Notes to Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements (Notes) and should be read in conjunction with such Statements and Notes.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>This combined MD&amp;A is separately filed by Public Service Enterprise Group Incorporated (PSEG), Public Service Electric and Gas Company (PSE&amp;G), PSEG Power LLC (Power), and PSEG Energy Holdings L.L.C. (Energy Holdings). Information contained herein relating to any individual company is filed by such company on its own behalf. PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings each make representations only as to itself and make no representations as to any other company.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Pending'>PENDING MERGER</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As previously disclosed, on December 20, 2004, PSEG entered into an agreement and plan of merger (Merger Agreement) with Exelon Corporation (Exelon), a public utility holding company registered under the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 (PUHCA), which is headquartered in Chicago, Illinois, whereby PSEG and its subsidiaries will be merged with and into Exelon (Merger). Under the Merger Agreement, each share of PSEG Common Stock will be converted into 1.225 shares of Exelon Common Stock.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The Merger Agreement has been unanimously approved by both companies&#39; Boards of Directors. On July&nbsp;19, 2005, shareholders of PSEG voted to approve the Merger, and on July&nbsp;22, 2005, shareholders of Exelon voted to approve the issuance of common shares to PSEG shareholders to effect the Merger.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Completion of the Merger is subject to approval by a number of governmental authorities, which may impose conditions on completion of the Merger, require changes to the terms of the Merger or fail to approve the Merger. The imposition of conditions or changes could have the effect of delaying completion of the Merger or imposing additional costs on or limiting the revenues of the combined company and/or the individual registrants following the Merger, any of which might have a material adverse effect on the combined company or the individual registrants following completion of the Merger. PSEG is committed to this proposed business combination; however, pending receipt of the various required approvals, which cannot be assured, PSEG intends to maintain a viable stand-alone business.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In the first quarter of 2005, Exelon and PSEG filed applications or made filings with the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC), the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities (BPU), the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission (PAPUC), the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC), the New York Public Service Commission (NYPSC), the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection (NJDEP) and the Connecticut Siting Council. Exelon and PSEG also made the filings required under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Antitrust Improvements Act of 1976 (HSR Act) and Exelon filed a private letter ruling on the transfer of nuclear decommissioning funds with the Internal Revenue Service. Additional applications and notices have been filed in subsequent months.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On June&nbsp;30, 2005, the FERC voted to approve the Merger. The FERC determined that Exelon&#39;s and PSEG&#39;s proposed divestitures and other commitments in their original and supplemental filings with FERC, together with their answers to intervenors&#39; questions, met the public interest standard of the Federal Power Act. Exelon and PSEG have committed to divest 4,000 megawatts (MW) of intermediate and peaking generation facilities located primarily in eastern PJM Interconnection L.L.C. (PJM), and to &ldquo;virtually divest&rdquo; 2,600&nbsp;MW of nuclear capacity by effectively transferring control of the output through sales to third parties.</font></p>
<p align=center>52</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>A number of parties, including the BPU, the American Public Power Association and the National Rural Electric Cooperative Association, have filed requests for rehearing of the decision made by FERC. In late August 2005, FERC issued a notice that it would respond to the rehearing request.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>During 2005, regulatory approvals or clearances related to the Merger have also been obtained from the Connecticut Siting Council regarding the transfer of PSEG Power Connecticut LLC&#39;s Certificate of Environmental Compatibility and Public Need to Exelon Generation Connecticut LLC, the NJDEP under the Industrial Site Recovery Act, the NYPSC and FERC with respect to the transfer of the hydro license for Yards Creek Generating Station. Approval of the transaction has also been obtained from the President of the Competition and Consumer Protection Office in Poland.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On June&nbsp;22, 2005, the BPU issued an oral decision stating that Exelon and PSEG will be required to prove that positive benefits flow to PSE&amp;G&#39;s customers as a result of the Merger, as well as no adverse impact to competition, employees, customers, rates or reliability due to the Merger. On August 11, 2005, the Administrative Law Judge (ALJ) in the proceeding before the BPU amended a prior pre-hearing order to modify the timetable for the regulatory approval process in New Jersey. The procedural schedule for the BPU proceedings includes opportunities for settlement discussions with the consumer advocacy groups and other interested parties during the course of the proceedings. The order provides for such hearings to commence in late November 2005. On October&nbsp;7, 2005, the ALJ approved a request from PSEG,
Exelon and the BPU staff to delay the hearings until January&nbsp;4, 2006. The postponement of the hearings does not impact the order&#39;s provision for settlement discussions in December 2005 after the positions of the parties involved have been filed or the ALJ to issue an initial decision by March&nbsp;30, 2006. Thereafter, pursuant to the provisions of the New Jersey Administrative Procedure Act, a decision of the full BPU could reasonably be expected by approximately May&nbsp;15, 2006.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In early September 2005, Exelon&#39;s wholly owned subsidiary, PECO Energy Company (PECO), filed with the PAPUC a settlement of most issues raised in Pennsylvania&#39;s review of the Merger. If the settlement is approved, PECO would provide $120 million over four years in rate discounts for customers and cap its rates through the end of 2010. The settlement also provides substantial funding for alternative energy and environmental projects, economic development, and expanded outreach and assistance for low-income customers. PECO also made commitments for enhanced customer and service reliability and pledges for charitable donations and maintenance of its current headquarters at current staff levels in Philadelphia until the end of 2010. The settlement was reached with consumer, business, environmental and low income consumer
advocates.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On September&nbsp;12, 2005, the ALJ in the proceeding before the PAPUC issued a revised pre-hearing order establishing a modified timetable for the regulatory approval process in Pennsylvania. The modified timetable permits parties to comment on PECO&#39;s settlement and unresolved issues under the settlement and accelerates the schedule for hearings and briefs. Accordingly, it is anticipated that the ALJ may issue an initial decision earlier than the previously expected date of mid-December 2005. It is possible that the full PAPUC will vote on the case before the end of 2005.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG and Exelon expect to complete their responses to the information requests of the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) under the HSR Act in the fourth quarter of 2005. Once the DOJ has evaluated the information submitted by PSEG, Exelon and others, PSEG and Exelon expect to discuss any suggestions or remedies proposed by the DOJ.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Commonwealth Edison (ComEd), a wholly owned subsidiary of Exelon, is involved in two regulatory proceedings in Illinois which would culminate for ComEd the restructuring of the electricity business in Illinois commenced in 1997. Pursuant to that restructuring, ComEd&#39;s rates were reduced until January&nbsp;1, 2007 and ComEd divested its electric generating stations to third parties, including to its affiliate, Exelon Generation Company, LLC (Exelon Generation). During the restructuring period, Exelon Generation has been required to supply power to ComEd pursuant to a contract which expires December&nbsp;31, 2006. One of the current proceedings involves a proposal by ComEd to procure power after January&nbsp;1, 2007 (Procurement Case) pursuant to an auction similar to the BGS auction in New Jersey. The other proceeding
is a rate case (Rate Case) for its distribution operations to establish new distribution rates effective January 1, 2007.</font></p>
<p align=center>53</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>It has been
  reported by Exelon that the ICC&#39;s final order on the Procurement Case is
  expected by January&nbsp;24, 2006, subject to the resolution of litigation instituted
  on September&nbsp;1, 2005 by the Illinois Attorney General, the Cook County
  State&#39;s Attorney, the Citizens Utility Board (CUB) and the Environmental
  Law and Public Policy Center seeking to block the ICC from approving the Procurement
  Case. The Illinois General Assembly has held hearings concerning generation
  procurement post-2006, and it may choose to take further action on this issue.
  The Governor of Illinois has expressed his opposition to the procurement process
  proposed in the Procurement Case. On September&nbsp;21, 2005, the Governor of
  Illinois appointed the former Executive Director of CUB, Mr. Martin Cohen, as
  the Chairman of the ICC. On October&nbsp;5, 2005, ComEd filed a motion with
  the ICC formally seeking recusal of Mr. Cohen from the Procurement Case.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Exelon reports that it cannot predict the results of the Procurement Case or the Rate Case before the ICC or whether the Illinois General Assembly might take action that could have a material impact on the outcome of the regulatory process. However, if the price at which ComEd is allowed to sell energy beginning in 2007 is below ComEd&#39;s cost to procure electricity, there may be material adverse consequences to ComEd and possibly Exelon.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The regulatory and political developments in Illinois may also have an effect on the settlement discussions and proceedings before the BPU and the PAPUC and could delay those regulatory approvals. Some possible outcomes of the developments in Illinois could have an effect on the timing or the closing conditions to the Merger.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Based on the current status of the regulatory approval process, Exelon and PSEG expect that, assuming all other conditions to completion of the Merger are satisfied, the Merger would be completed in the first quarter of 2006 if the regulatory proceedings before the BPU and the PAPUC are settled and approved before the dates on which those state authorities are expected to rule on the Merger in the absence of a settlement, as discussed above. If early settlements are not reached and approved, then the parties expect that, assuming all other conditions are satisfied, the Merger should be completed in the second quarter of 2006.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Although Exelon and PSEG believe that the expectations as to timing for the closing of the Merger described above are reasonable, no assurances can be given as to the timing of the receipt of any required regulatory approvals or that all required approvals will be received. In the event the Merger does not close, management believes PSEG will continue to operate successfully, however, inability to close the pending Merger with Exelon could have a material adverse effect on the financial condition, results of operations and cash flows of PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Overview'>OVERVIEW</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Prior to the completion of the Merger, PSEG and Exelon, and their respective subsidiaries, will continue to operate as separate entities. The discussion contained in the MD&amp;A that follows relates solely to the current businesses of PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings and their respective expectations for future financial position, results of operations and cash flows, exclusive of any potential impacts from the proposed Merger.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Market Price Environment</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>There has been a significant increase in commodity prices, including fuel, emission allowances and electricity. Over the last year, both natural gas and electric prices in PJM have more than doubled. Price increases of this magnitude are much greater than have been experienced in recent history and could have a considerable effect on PSEG&#39;s businesses. For Power, a rising price environment can result in increased cost to produce electricity, particularly with gas-fired generation, higher replacement power costs, including power that must be purchased when unplanned outages occur, potential alteration of the dispatch order of units based upon fuel choice and efficiency, changes to the pricing environment in which companies contract for fuel and electricity and higher liquidity requirements. For PSE&amp;G, a rising commodity
price environment results in higher delivered electric and gas rates for end use</font></p>
<p align=center>54</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>customers, and may result in decreased demand by end users of both electricity and gas and greater working capital requirements as the collection of higher commodity costs may be deferred into future periods.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>During the nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2005 the rising commodity price environment resulted in increased liquidity requirements for Power&#39;s energy sales contracts entered into in the normal course of business (See Liquidity and Capital Resources for additional information). In addition, Accumulated Other Comprehensive Loss (OCL) increased as contracts that qualify for hedge accounting were marked to market (See Other Comprehensive Loss for additional information).</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Over the next few years, management believes that a rising commodity price environment will serve to increase profitability for Power because higher prices should result in greater margin opportunity as existing contracts expire and higher prices are realized, assuming generating plants operate as planned. Management also believes that Power has sufficient liquidity to meet margin requirements associated with forward contracts to sell energy.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG&#39;s business consists of four reportable segments, which are PSE&amp;G, Power and the two direct subsidiaries of Energy Holdings: PSEG Global L.L.C. (Global) and PSEG Resources L.L.C. (Resources). The following is a discussion of the markets in which PSEG and its subsidiaries compete, the corporate strategy for the conduct of PSEG&#39;s businesses within these markets, significant events that have occurred during the first nine months of 2005 and expectations for the full-year 2005 and beyond.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>For the nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2005, PSEG had Income from Continuing Operations of $653 million, or $2.68 diluted per share. PSEG continues to project Income from Continuing Operations for 2005 of $3.15 to $3.35 per share. Included in its projections for 2005 were $60 million to $70 million of expenses at the PSEG parent level, primarily due to financing costs. It is expected that costs associated with the proposed Merger could reduce 2005 results by as much as $0.10 to $0.15 per share, which is not included in the earnings projection noted above.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>For 2006, PSEG expects Income from Continuing Operations to range from $3.45 to $3.75 per share. The increase as compared to current 2005 earnings projections is primarily due to anticipated increased earnings at Power. The projected increase at Power is due to anticipated higher margins through the expiration of existing contracts and the realization of current and anticipated higher market prices. Also assumed in the earnings projections for 2006 are reasonable outcomes to PSE&amp;G&#39;s gas and electric rate cases and continued strong contributions from Global&#39;s operations in Texas and South America.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G operates as an electric and gas public utility in New Jersey under cost-based regulation by the BPU for its distribution operations and by the FERC for its electric transmission and wholesale sales operations. Consequently, the earnings of PSE&amp;G are largely determined by the regulation of its rates by those agencies. For the nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2005, PSE&amp;G had Net Income of $282 million. PSE&amp;G expects Income from Continuing Operations to range from $325 million to $345 million for 2005, based on normal weather conditions, expected growth in electricity and natural gas sales and productivity gains, partially offset by operating cost increases.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G provides electricity under two types of basic generation service (BGS) through a BPU-administered auction for customers that do not have a third party to source their electric supply requirements. BGS-Fixed Price (FP) provides supply for smaller commercial and residential customers at seasonally-adjusted fixed prices. PSE&amp;G&#39;s total BGS-FP load is approximately 8,600&nbsp;MW. Approximately one-third of this total load is expected to be auctioned off each year for a three-year term. BGS-Commercial and Industrial Energy Price (CIEP) provides supply for larger customers at hourly PJM real-time market prices for a term of 12&nbsp;months. BGS-FP and BGS-CIEP represent approximately 84% and 16%, respectively, of PSE&amp;G&#39;s current load.</font></p>
<p align=center>55</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In February 2005, the BPU approved the results of New Jersey&#39;s annual BGS-FP and BGS-CIEP auctions and PSE&amp;G successfully secured contracts to provide the electricity requirements for its customers&#39; needs.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>BGS-FP rates change annually on June&nbsp;1 and are based on the average BGS price obtained at auction in the current year and two prior years. PSE&amp;G&#39;s current pricing is as follows:</font></p>
<table width=100% cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0><tr bgcolor=#ffffff>

</table>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On September&nbsp;30, 2005, PSE&amp;G filed a petition with the BPU seeking an overall 3.78% increase in its gas base rates to appropriately recover the cost of gas delivery and to be effective June&nbsp;30, 2006. Approximately $55 million of the $132.8 million request is for an increase in book depreciation rates. The balance of the request will cover increased plant investment, higher operating expenses and provide an 11% return on equity. PSE&amp;G&#39;s current gas base rates have been in effect since January 2002.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Gas Commodity Prices</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G makes no margin on gas commodity sales as the costs are directly passed through to customers. The difference between gas costs incurred and the Basic Gas Supply Service (BGSS) revenues received from customers is deferred and collected from or returned to customers in future periods. However, the significant increase in the price of natural gas, as discussed previously, impacts PSE&amp;G&#39;s revenues and expenses in a number of ways.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Gas Supply</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Gas commodity prices fluctuate monthly for commercial and industrial (C&amp;I) customers so price increases are immediately reflected in the revenues and gas costs for those customers. For example, the majority of BGSS C&amp;I customers paid $1.38 per therm in September 2005, an 83% increase over the $0.75 per therm paid in September 2004. The higher prices have and will continue to negatively impact delivery sales volumes.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The gas commodity price for residential customers under the BGSS tariff is set annually, usually on October&nbsp;1. In addition, for residential gas customers, PSE&amp;G has the ability to adjust rates upward two additional times and downward at any time, if warranted, between annual BGSS proceedings. The difference between costs and the amount recovered from customers in revenues is deferred and collected from or returned to customers in future periods.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On August&nbsp;19, 2005, the BPU approved an increase for residential customers of 10.6%, which became effective on September&nbsp;1, 2005. This increase was based on a May 2005 forecast of gas cost through September 2006. The new charge of $0.87 per therm is significantly lower than the C&amp;I commodity rate because PSE&amp;G has hedged a portion of future load at lower prices. PSE&amp;G has the right to increase rates up to 5% on both December 1 and February 1 without BPU approval. Based on the current forecast, if no additional increase is permitted, PSE&amp;G could have a deferred gas balance well in excess of $200 million by September 2006. Even if the two 5% increases were implemented, the deferred gas balance could exceed $100 million by September 2006 with current prices. PSE&amp;G does not recover the carrying
costs on gas under recoveries. PSE&amp;G is working closely with the BPU to address the rising gas costs.</font></p>
<p align=center>56</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Electric Supply</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The PJM on-peak locational marginal price is directly impacted by higher gas prices. Approximately 84% of PSE&amp;G&#39;s load is provided by BGS-FP contracts. One-third of this load is auctioned off each year for a three-year term which dampens the impact of current pricing. The remaining 16% of the load is provided through BGS-CIEP contracts to larger customers at hourly PJM real-time market prices for a term of 12&nbsp;months so price increases are immediately reflected in the revenues and electric costs for these customers. Both BGS tariffs provide current rate recovery in the next billing period. Therefore, the deferred balance at any given month end is relatively small.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power is an electric generation and wholesale energy marketing and trading company that focuses on the generation market extending from Maine to the Carolinas and the Atlantic Coast to Indiana (Region). Power&#39;s principal operating subsidiaries are PSEG Fossil LLC (Fossil), PSEG Nuclear LLC (Nuclear) and PSEG Energy Resources &amp; Trade LLC (ER&amp;T). Through its subsidiaries, Power seeks to balance the output of its generating capacity, fuel requirements and supply obligations through integrated portfolio management, enhance its ability to produce low-cost energy through efficient nuclear and fossil operations and pursue growth in the Region based on market conditions.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As a result of the increases in market prices, Power expects substantial increases in earnings for 2006. For 2006, Power had entered into contracts for 85% to 90% of its nuclear and coal-fired generation. Also, for 2007 and 2008, Power has been actively terming-up future period sales to capture the value of its nuclear and coal-fired generation, given recent market conditions. As of mid-October, 2005, Power had met its stated objective of contracting at least 75% of its anticipated output over an&nbsp;18-24 month horizon, including terming-up between 65% and 75% of its anticipated nuclear and coal-fired generation for 2007, and between 35% and 45% of its nuclear and coal-fired generation for 2008. Changes in the operation of Power&#39;s generating facilities, fuel and capacity prices, expected contract prices, capacity
factors or other assumptions could materially affect its ability to meet earnings targets.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power&#39;s objective is to enter into load-serving contracts, firm sales and trading positions for at least 75% of its anticipated output over an 18-month to 24-month horizon. Power has achieved this objective through a combination of contracts related to the BGS auctions in New Jersey, contracts with local electric distribution companies (EDCs) in Pennsylvania and Connecticut and other firm sales and trading positions. As mentioned above, in February 2005, the BPU approved the results of the BGS auction process for New Jersey customers. Power continues to be a direct supplier of New Jersey EDCs under both the BGS-FP and BGS-CIEP auctions, entering into additional contracts that began on June&nbsp;1, 2005. Power believes that its obligations under these contracts are reasonably balanced by its available supply. Power continues
to believe that entering into contracts for at least 75% of its anticipated generation output is an appropriate way to reduce the volatility of its earnings.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On September 28, 2005, Power completed the sale of its electric generation facility located in Waterford, Ohio (Waterford) to a subsidiary of American Electric Power Company, Inc. The sale price for the facility and inventory is $220 million. The proceeds, together with anticipated reduction in tax liability, are approximately $320 million, which will be used to retire debt at Power. See Note&nbsp;3. Discontinued Operations, Dispositions and Acquisitions of the Notes for further discussion.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>During 2005, Power began collecting a monthly fixed payment amount for reliability services provided by its generating facilities in Connecticut, retroactive to November&nbsp;18, 2004. Based on a FERC order issued in late April 2005 and effective February&nbsp;24, 2005, subject to refund and hearing, Power has also begun receiving payments for reliability services provided by the Sewaren Station, Units&nbsp;1, 2, 3 and 4 and Hudson Station, Unit&nbsp;1. These payments provide compensation to a generation owner when a unit proposed for retirement must continue operating for reliability purposes. Such payments are net of operating margins at the units in both markets.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On July&nbsp;18, 2005, Power&#39;s new Bethlehem Energy Center (BEC), a 750 MW, natural gas&nbsp;-fired combined cycle power generation plant near Albany, New York, began commercial operations.</font></p>
<p align=center>57</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>A key factor in Power&#39;s ability to achieve its objectives is its capability to operate its nuclear and fossil stations at sufficient capacity factors to avoid the need to purchase higher-priced electricity to satisfy its obligations. Concurrent with the signing of the Merger Agreement, Power entered into an Operating Services Contract (OSC) with Exelon Generation. Under the terms of the OSC, since January&nbsp;17, 2005, Exelon Generation has provided management personnel and its proprietary management systems under a fee arrangement to Power to operate the Salem and Hope Creek nuclear generating facilities. In May 2005, a scheduled refueling outage at Salem Unit 2 was completed ahead of schedule while meeting self-imposed nuclear safety targets.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>For the nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2005, Power had Income from Continuing Operations of $303 million. Power expects Income from Continuing Operations to range from $335 million to $385 million in 2005. For the nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2005, Power had Net Income of $106 million, which includes a Loss from Discontinued Operations of $197 million, including Loss on Disposal related to Waterford, discussed above.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Energy Holdings, through Global, owns and operates electric generation and distribution facilities in international and U.S. markets. The generation plants sell power under long-term agreements, as well as on a merchant basis, while the distribution companies are rate-regulated enterprises. Through Resources, Energy Holdings invests in energy-related financial transactions, including leveraged leases, which are designed to produce predictable earnings and cash flows.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>For the nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2005, Energy Holdings had Net Income of $140 million. Based on current earnings, Energy Holdings believes that Income from Continuing Operations for 2005 could exceed its previously projected range of $135 million to $155 million, reflecting improved results from Texas Independent Energy, L.P. (TIE), lower financing costs and the absence of foreign currency losses at Elektrocieplownia Chorzow Sp. z o.o. (ELCHO) which are expected to more than offset the loss of earnings due to the sale of Meiya Power Company Limited (MPC) and the partial sale of Luz del Sur S.A.A. (LDS) in 2004.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Global continues to limit its capital spending, while focusing on operations and improved performance of existing businesses and is seeking to opportunistically monetize investments that may no longer have a strategic fit. In April 2005, Global sold a 35% interest in Dhofar Power Company S.A.O.C. (Dhofar Power), reducing its ownership interest from 81% to 46%, through a public offering on the Omani stock exchange for net proceeds of approximately $25 million.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The capital requirements of Global&#39;s consolidated subsidiaries are primarily financed from internally generated cash flow within the projects and from local sources on a non-recourse basis or limited discretionary investments by Energy Holdings.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Under a provision of The American Jobs Creation Act of 2004 (Jobs Act), Global has a one-year window to repatriate earnings from its foreign investments and claim a special one-time 85% dividends received tax deduction on such distributions. To date during 2005, PSEG has approved Domestic Reinvestment Plans which provide for the repatriation of approximately $182 million, of which $140 million is eligible for the reduced tax rate pursuant to the Jobs Act. The tax expense associated with such repatriation totaled approximately $9 million and was recorded in the quarter ended September&nbsp;30, 2005. In addition, Global&#39;s projections indicate that additional earnings could be generated by its international investments over the balance of 2005 that could increase the amount of funds that could reasonably be considered
for repatriation in 2005 by approximately $50 million, which would result in an additional $2 million of tax expense. Global has made no change in its current intention to indefinitely reinvest accumulated earnings of its foreign subsidiaries.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Resources is focused on maintaining its current investment portfolio and does not expect to make any new investments. Resources&#39; objective is to produce predictable cash flows, earnings and related tax benefits. Resources&#39; ability to realize tax benefits associated with its leveraged lease investments is dependent upon operating gains generated by its affiliates. Resources&#39; earnings and cash flows are expected to decrease in the future as the investment portfolio matures.</font></p>
<p align=center>58</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In January 2005, Resources and Global sold their interests in three Solar Electric Generating Systems (SEGS) projects for proceeds of approximately $7 million and Resources received proceeds of&nbsp;approximately $17 million from the KKR Fund&#39;s sale of its investment in KinderCare Learning Centers,&nbsp;Inc.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In June 2005, Resources wrote off its entire investment of approximately $15 million, net of tax, in an aircraft lease to United Airlines (UAL) upon termination of the lease and repossession of the aircraft by the lenders in a bankruptcy proceeding with UAL.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of September&nbsp;30, 2005, Resources has a remaining gross investment in four leased aircraft of approximately $36 million. On September&nbsp;14, 2005, Delta Airlines (Delta) and Northwest Airlines (Northwest), the lessees for Resources&#39; four remaining aircraft, filed for Chapter&nbsp;11 bankruptcy protection. This had no material effect on Energy Holdings as it continues to believe that it will be able to fully recover the recorded amount of its investments in these aircraft.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Resources continues to monitor the accounting and tax treatment of certain leases in its portfolio. For additional information, see Note&nbsp;5. Commitments and Contingent Liabilities of the Notes.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Results'>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The results for PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings for the quarter and nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2005 and 2004 are presented below:</font></p>

<p align=center>59</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><i><font color=#000000>(footnotes from previous page)</font></i></p>
<table  cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0><tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=right valign=top><font color=#000000>&nbsp;</font></td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=right valign=top><font color=#000000>(A)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=bottom nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=bottom><font color=#000000>Other activities include non-segment amounts of Energy Holdings and its subsidiaries and intercompany eliminations. Specific amounts include interest on certain financing transactions and certain other administrative and general expenses at Energy Holdings.</font></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=right valign=top><font color=#000000>&nbsp;</font></td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=right valign=top><font color=#000000>(B)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=bottom nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=bottom><font color=#000000>Other activities include non-segment amounts of PSEG (as parent company) and intercompany eliminations. Specific amounts include preferred securities dividends/preference unit distributions for PSE&amp;G and Energy Holdings, interest on certain financing transactions and Merger expenses and certain other administrative and general expenses at PSEG (as parent company).</font></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=right valign=top><font color=#000000>&nbsp;</font></td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=right valign=top><font color=#000000>(C)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=bottom nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=bottom><font color=#000000>Includes Discontinued Operations at Power in 2005 and 2004 and Energy Holdings in 2004. See Note 3. Discontinued Operations, Dispositions and Acquisitions of the Notes.</font></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=right valign=top><font color=#000000>&nbsp;</font></td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=right valign=top><font color=#000000>(D)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=bottom nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=bottom><font color=#000000>Earnings per Share of any segment does not represent a direct legal interest in the assets and liabilities allocated to any one segment but rather represents a direct interest in PSEG&#39;s assets and liabilities as a whole.</font></td></tr>
</table>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $8 million increase in Income from Continuing Operations for the quarter primarily resulted from an increase in electric commodity revenues at PSE&amp;G due to higher weather-related demand, higher realized gains in Power&#39;s Nuclear Decommissioning Trust (NDT) portfolio and improved earnings at Global due to improved operations at TIE and favorable foreign currency exchange rates. Partially offsetting these increases were Merger-related costs of approximately $10 million, net of tax, at PSEG, higher interest expense at the PSEG parent level, higher prices for replacement energy and fuel costs at Power and $9 million of tax expense for one-time dividends that were repatriated from Global&#39;s international investments pursuant to the Jobs Act.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $8 million decrease in Income from Continuing Operations for the nine months was primarily due to lower earnings at Power, reflecting higher prices for replacement energy and fuel costs partially offset by higher prices from sales of electricity in the spot market and higher Reliability-Must-Run revenues. In addition, Merger-related costs of approximately $26 million, net of tax at PSEG and Power contributed to the overall decline in Income from Continuing Operations. These decreases were substantially offset by higher earnings at Global due to the reasons discussed above.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The change in Net Income for the nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2005 included a decrease of $170 million from the Loss from Discontinued Operations at Power from the sale of Waterford in 2005 and a decrease of $5 million from Income from Discontinued Operations at Energy Holdings from the sale of its majority interest in Carthage Power Company in 2004.</font></p>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG&#39;s results of operations are primarily comprised of the results of operations of its operating subsidiaries, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings, excluding changes related to intercompany transactions, which are eliminated in consolidation and certain financing costs at the parent company. For additional information on intercompany transactions, see Note&nbsp;12. Related-Party Transactions of the Notes. For a discussion of the causes for the variances at PSEG in the table above, see the discussions for PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings that follow.</font></p>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Operating Revenues</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G has three sources of revenue: commodity revenues from the sales of energy to customers and in the PJM spot market; delivery revenues from the transmission and distribution of energy through its system; and other operating revenues from the provision of various services. The $298 million increase for the quarter ended September&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was due to an increase of $224 million in commodity revenues, described below, and $72 million in delivery revenues. The $323 million increase for the nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was due to increases of $266 million in commodity revenues, described below, $52 million in delivery revenues and $5 million in other operating revenues, primarily related to appliance service contracts.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Commodity</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G makes no margin on commodity sales as the costs are passed through to customers. The difference between costs and the amount provided by customers in revenues is deferred and collected from or returned to customers in future periods. Total commodity volumes and revenues are subject to market forces. Gas commodity prices fluctuate monthly for commercial and industrial customers and annually through the BGSS tariff for residential customers. In addition, for residential gas customers, PSE&amp;G has the ability to adjust rates upward two additional times and downward at any time, if warranted, between annual BGSS proceedings. Electric commodity prices are set at the annual BGS auctions.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $224 million increase in commodity revenues for the quarter ended September&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was due to increases of $171 million in electric commodity revenues, $106 million primarily due to higher BGS prices and $65 million in higher volumes due to weather. Also contributing to the increase was $53 million in increased gas commodity revenues, $38 million primarily due to higher BGSS prices, offset by an $8 million decrease due to the expiration of the Third Party Shopping Incentive on July&nbsp;1, 2005. There is a corresponding $8 million increase in delivery revenues, described below. Also contributing to the increase is $23 million in higher volumes, primarily due to increased cogeneration operations.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $266 million increase in commodity revenues for the nine months ended September 30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was due to increases of $163 million in electric commodity</font></p>
<p align=center>61</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>revenues, $117 million primarily due to higher BGS prices and $46 million in higher volumes due to weather. Also contributing to the increase was $103 million in increased gas commodity revenues, $101 million primarily due to higher BGSS prices, offset by an $8 million decrease due to the expiration of the Third Party Shopping Incentive on July&nbsp;1, 2005, and a $10 million increase primarily due to increased cogeneration operations.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Delivery</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $72 million increase in delivery revenues for the quarter ended September&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was due to increases of $67 million in electric revenues and $5 million in gas revenues. The $67 million increase in electric delivery revenues was primarily due to higher volumes due to weather of $69 million offset by decreased prices of $2 million due to decreased distribution prices. The $5 million increase in gas delivery revenues was primarily due to the expiration of the Third Party Shopping Incentive on July&nbsp;1, 2005, resulting in an increase of $8 million in delivery revenues with a corresponding offset in commodity revenues, described above. This was offset by $2 million in lower volume and demand revenues due to weather and $3 million due to the expiration of the Gas Cost Underrecovery
Adjustment (GCUA) clause in January 2005.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $52 million increase in delivery revenues for the nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was due to a $69 million increase in electric delivery revenues, partially offset by a $17 million decrease in gas delivery revenues. The $69 million increase in electric delivery revenues was primarily due to higher volume revenues of $58 million due to weather and $11 million in higher rates. The $17 million decrease in gas delivery revenues was primarily due to a $23 million decrease related to the expiration of the GCUA clause in January 2005 and $12 million in lower volume and demand revenues due to weather. These were offset by a $13 million increase in SBC rates, primarily due to the USF component. SBC rates are recorded with a corresponding offset in Operating Expenses, described
below, resulting in no impact to Net Income. Also offsetting the decrease is an $8 million increase due to the expiration of the Third Party Shopping Incentive on July 1, 2005, which is offset in commodity revenues, described above.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Operating Expenses</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Energy Costs</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $235 million increase for the quarter ended September&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was comprised of increases of $179 million in electric costs and $56 million in gas costs. The electric increase was due to a $124 million or 13% increase related to higher prices for BGS and Non-Utility Generation (NUG) purchases and a $55 million increase due to higher BGS volumes. The increase in gas costs was caused by a $41 million or 22% increase in gas prices and an $18 million increase due to higher sales volumes due primarily to higher interruptible sales offset by a $3 million decrease due to the expiration of the GCUA clause in January 2005, described above.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $269 million increase for the nine months ended September 30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was comprised of increases of $180 million in electric costs and $89 million in gas costs. The increase in electric costs was caused by a $167 million or 6% increase due to higher prices for BGS and NUG purchases and a $61 million increase due to higher BGS volumes, partially offset by a decrease of $47 million due to lower NUG volumes. The increased gas costs were due to a $98 million or 9% increase in gas prices and a $13 million increase in sales volumes due primarily to higher sales to cogenerators. These were offset by a $23 million decrease due to the expiration of the GCUA clause in January 2005, described above.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Operation and Maintenance</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $15 million increase for the quarter ended September 30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was due primarily to $7 million in labor and fringe benefits due to increased wages and staffing and increased SBC expenses of $5 million.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $42 million increase for the nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was due primarily to increased SBC expenses of $26 million and $16 million in labor and fringe benefits, respectively, due to increased wages and staffing.</font></p>
<p align=center>62</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Depreciation and Amortization</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $15 million increase for the quarter ended September 30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was due primarily to a $20 million increase in the amortization of the Securitization regulatory asset. This was offset by a $3 million decrease in software amortization and a $2 million increase in excess depreciation reserve amortization.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $25 million increase for the nine months ended September 30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was due primarily to a $25 million increase in the amortization of the Securitization regulatory asset, a $4 million increase due to additional plant in service and a $3 million increase in the amortization of the Remediation Adjustment Clause (RAC). These were offset by a $5 million decrease in software amortization and a $2 million increase in excess depreciation reserve amortization.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Interest Expense</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $17 million decrease for the nine months ended September 30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was due to decreases of $24 million due to lower average interest rates and lower amounts of long-term debt outstanding. This was partially offset by increases of $5 million due to higher short-term interest rates and higher amounts of short-term debt outstanding.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Income Taxes</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $4 million increase for the quarter ended September 30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was primarily due to higher&nbsp;pre-tax income of $11 million offset by $4 million in various flow-thru benefits and $3 million in prior period adjustments recorded in 2004.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $4 million decrease for the nine months ended September 30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was due to lower&nbsp;pre-tax income of $1 million and $3 million in prior period adjustments in 2004.</font></p>

<td align=left valign=bottom><p style='margin-left:1em;text-indent:-1em;'></p></td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td></tr>
</table>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Operating Revenues</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $314 million increase for the quarter ended September 30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was due to increases of $284 million in generation revenues and $61 million in gas supply revenues partially offset by a decrease of $31 million in trading revenues.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $416 million increase for the nine months ended September 30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was due to increases of $299 million in generation revenues and $130 million in gas supply revenues partly offset by a decrease of $13 million in trading revenues.</font></p>
<p align=center>63</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Generation</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The increase of $284 million in generation revenues for the quarter ended September 30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was due principally to increases of approximately $70 million from operations in New&nbsp;York, largely due to BEC which began commercial operations on July&nbsp;18, 2005 and approximately $64 million from sales in the power pools due to favorable weather conditions and pricing. Also contributing to the increase were approximately $39 million from higher load being served and higher pricing under the BGS contracts, $33 million from higher volumes sold under other wholesale contracts, $32 million from increased ancillary services and operating reserves and higher unrealized gains on asset-backed transactions of approximately $42 million.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The increase of $299 million in generation revenues for the nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was primarily due to increases of approximately $43 million related to Reliability Must-Run (RMR) revenues which Power began receiving in 2005 for certain of its generating facilities, approximately $56 million from operations in New&nbsp;York, largely due to BEC&#39;s operations which were partially offset by operations of the Albany Steam Station which was operational in 2004 and retired in February 2005, approximately $75 million from new contracts and approximately $33 million from increased sales and higher pricing in the various power pools partially offset by reduced load being served under the fixed-priced BGS contracts. Also contributing to the increase were approximately
$45 million from increased ancillary services and operating reserves and higher unrealized gains on asset-backed transactions of approximately $32 million.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Gas Supply</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $61 million increase in gas supply revenues for the quarter ended September&nbsp;30, 2005 as compared to the same period for 2004, was primarily due to increases of approximately $42 million from higher gas prices and higher demand under the BGSS contract with PSE&amp;G and approximately $18 million from higher prices for gas and pipeline capacity sold to other gas distributors partially offset by lower demand from other gas distributors.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $130 million increase for the nine months ended September 30, 2005, as compared to the same periods in 2004, was principally due to higher prices for gas and pipeline capacity partially offset by lower demand.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Trading</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $31 million and $13 million decrease in trading revenues for the quarter and nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2005, respectively, as compared to the same period in 2004, was primarily due to market conditions.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Operating Expenses</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Energy Costs</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Energy Costs represent the cost of generation, which includes fuel purchases for generation as well as purchased energy in the market, and gas purchases to meet Power&#39;s obligation under its BGSS contract with PSE&amp;G. The $347 million and $397 million increase for the quarter and nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2005, respectively, as compared to the same periods in 2004, was primarily due to increased generation and replacement power costs, reflecting higher demand and pricing due to weather conditions, operation of BEC since July 2005 and higher fossil fuel prices as well as higher prices for gas purchased to satisfy Power&#39;s BGSS obligations.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Operation and Maintenance</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $12 million increase for the quarter ended September 30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was primarily due to a $12 million settlement received from the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) in 2004 as reimbursement for nuclear waste storage costs incurred due to the delay in</font></p>
<p align=center>64</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>construction of a federal storage facility. See Note 5. Commitments and Contingent Liabilities of the Notes&mdash;Nuclear Fuel Disposal.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $13 million increase for the nine months ended September 30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was primarily due to the $12 million DOE settlement in 2004, a $14 million restructuring charge recorded in 2005 related to Nuclear&#39;s workforce realignment plan, and higher costs of approximately $10 million related to Hope Creek&#39;s outage to complete Phase I of its turbine replacement in January 2005 and the Hope Creek outages for equipment repairs in March, June and August 2005. These increases were partially offset by $9 million of lower real estate taxes and $8 million of lower co-owner billings related to Power&#39;s jointly-owned facilities.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Depreciation and Amortization</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $5 million and $18 million increase for the quarter and nine months ended September 30, 2005, respectively, as compared to the same periods in 2004, was due to BEC facility being placed into service in July 2005 and a higher depreciable asset base in 2005 at Nuclear. The increase for the nine months ended September 30, 2005 also included the Lawrenceburg facility being placed into service in June 2004.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Other Income</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $38 million increase in Other Income for the quarter ended September 30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was primarily due to higher realized gains of approximately $34 million from the NDT Funds and a $5 million gain from the sale in September 2005 of four gas turbine generators located in Burlington, New Jersey.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $5 million decrease in Other Income for the nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was primarily due to decreased realized gains and income related to the NDT Funds partially offset by a $5 million gain from the sale in September 2005 of four gas turbine generators located in Burlington, New Jersey.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Other Deductions</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $11 million decrease for the nine months ended September 30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was primarily due to a write-off of $5 million of unamortized issuance costs related to the extinguishment of non-recourse project financing related to the Lawrenceburg facility in the first quarter of 2004 and decreased losses and expenses related to the NDT Funds.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Income Taxes</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $4 million decrease for the quarter ended September 30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was primarily due to lower&nbsp;pre-tax income.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $9 million increase for nine months ended September 30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was due to a decrease in taxes on pre-tax income of $3 million offset by increases in taxes of $12 million, due primarily from recording prior period adjustments in 2004 and recording taxes for the NDT Funds.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Loss from Discontinued Operations, including Loss on Disposal, net of tax</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On May 27, 2005, Power reached an agreement to sell its Waterford generation facility for approximately $220 million and recognized an estimated loss on disposal of $177 million, net of tax, for the initial write-down of its carrying amount of Waterford to its fair value less cost to sell. On September&nbsp;28, 2005, Power completed the sale of Waterford and recognized an additional loss of $1 million. The proceeds, together with anticipated reduction in tax liability, are approximately $320 million, which will be used to retire debt at Power. See Note&nbsp;3. Discontinued Operations, Dispositions and Acquisitions of the Notes for additional information.</font></p>
<p align=center>65</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">

<tr bgcolor=#e5ffff>
<td align=left valign=bottom><p style='margin-left:1em;text-indent:-1em;'><font color=#000000>Other Income</font></p></td>
<td align=right valign=bottom nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td align=right valign=bottom nowrap><font color=#000000>$</font></td>
<td align=right valign=bottom><font color=#000000>5</font></td>

<td align=right valign=bottom><font color=#000000>4</font></td>
<td bgcolor=#e5ffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=right valign=bottom nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>

<td align=right valign=bottom><font color=#000000>5</font></td>
<td bgcolor=#e5ffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=right valign=bottom nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td align=right valign=bottom nowrap><font color=#000000>$</font></td>

<td align=right valign=bottom><font color=#000000>(100</font></td>
<td align=left valign=bottom nowrap><font color=#000000>)</font></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=bottom><p style='margin-left:1em;text-indent:-1em;'></p></td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>

<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>

<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>

<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
