<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td></tr>
</table>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The variances in Operating Revenues, Energy Costs, Operation and Maintenance, Depreciation and Amortization and Income from Equity Method Investments were primarily attributed to Global&#39;s acquisition of the remaining interests in TIE, thus consolidating the entity effective July&nbsp;1, 2004, increased revenues at TIE in the third quarter of 2005 compared to same period in 2004 due to a stronger market and stronger spark spread (the difference between the market price of electricity and its cost of gas production) and Global&#39;s sale of a 35% interest in Dhofar Power through a public offering on the Omani Stock Exchange in April 2005, reducing its ownership interest to 46% and thus accounting for the investment under the equity method of accounting following the sale. For additional information, see Note&nbsp;3. Discontinued
Operations, Dispositions and Acquisitions of the Notes.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Operating Revenues</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $68 million increase for the quarter ended September 30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was due to higher revenues at Global of $73 million, including a $58 million increase due to higher revenues at TIE related to increased output and higher market prices, a $25 million increase related to Sociedad Austral de Electricidad S.A. (SAESA) in Chile due to higher energy sales volumes offset by a $16 million decrease related to the deconsolidation of Dhofar Power. Offsetting the increase were lower revenues at Resources of $5 million primarily due to a reduction in leveraged lease income related to the termination of the Lovelock LNG leveraged lease in December 2004.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $384 million increase for the nine months ended September 30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was due to higher revenues at Global of $395 million, including a $279 million increase related to the consolidation of TIE commencing July&nbsp;1, 2004 and $58 million due to higher revenues at TIE in the third quarter of 2005, a $49 million increase related to SAESA due to higher energy sales volumes, a $22 million increase related to Electrownia Skawina S.A. (Skawina) and a $12 million increase related to Global&#39;s investment in ELCHO, both due to higher energy sales in the spot market and higher Polish Zloty foreign exchange rates offset by a $28 million decrease related to the deconsolidation of Dhofar Power. Offsetting the increase were lower revenues at Resources of $11 million primarily due to a $22
million&nbsp;pre-tax write-off of its UAL Lease investment and a $5 million reduction in leveraged lease income offset by the absence of a $17 million&nbsp;pre-tax charge recorded in 2004 to reduce the carrying value of the Collins lease.</font></p>
<p align=center>66</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Operating Expenses</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Energy Costs</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $55 million increase for the quarter ended September 30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was primarily due to a $37 million increase related to TIE due to higher gas prices in 2005 compared to 2004, a $19 million increase related to SAESA due to significant increases in energy costs related to higher sales volumes and a $3 million increase related to Skawina due to higher energy sales in the spot market and higher Polish Zloty foreign exchange rates, offset by a $4 million decrease related to the deconsolidation of Dhofar Power.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $310 million increase for the nine months ended September 30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was primarily due to a $219 million increase related to the consolidation of TIE commencing July&nbsp;1, 2004, a $37 million increase in energy costs at TIE in the third quarter of 2005, a $40 million increase related to SAESA due to significant increases in energy costs and a $17 million increase related to Skawina due to higher energy sales in the spot market and higher Polish Zloty foreign exchange rates, offset by an $8 million decrease related to the deconsolidation of Dhofar Power.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Operation and Maintenance</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $6 million decrease for the quarter ended September 30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was primarily due to a $3 million decrease in administration and general expenses.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $44 million increase for the nine months ended September 30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was primarily due to a $41 million increase related to the consolidation of TIE commencing July&nbsp;1, 2004 offset by a $4 million decrease related to the deconsolidation of Dhofar Power.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Depreciation and Amortization</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $1 million decrease for the quarter ended September 30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was primarily due to the deconsolidation of Dhofar Power.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $5 million increase for the nine months ended September 30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was primarily due to a $9 million increase related to the consolidation of TIE commencing July&nbsp;1, 2004 offset by a $5 million decrease related to the deconsolidation of Dhofar Power.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Income from Equity Method Investments</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $2 million decrease for the quarter ended September 30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was primarily due to a $5 million decrease related to the loss of earnings associated with the sale of Global&#39;s equity interest in MPC in December 2004 and a $5 million decrease related to Global&#39;s investment in Prisma 2000 S.p.A. (Prisma), offset by an $8 million increase due to stronger results in South America.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $4 million increase for the nine months ended September 30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was primarily due to an $11 million increase due to stronger results in South America, the absence of a $3 million loss recognized in the nine months of 2004 from TIE, which was accounted for under the equity method of accounting until July&nbsp;1, 2004, and a $1 million increase related to the deconsolidation of Dhofar Power, thus accounting for the investment under the equity method of accounting following the sale, offset by an $8 million decrease related to the loss of earnings associated with the sale of Global&#39;s equity interest in MPC in December 2004 and a $3 million decrease related to Global&#39;s investment in Prisma.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Other Income</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $1 million increase for the quarter ended September 30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was primarily due to foreign currency transaction gains.</font></p>
<p align=center>67</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $10 million increase for the nine months ended September 30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was primarily due to foreign currency transaction gains of $9 million due to strengthening of the U.S. Dollar relative to the Polish Zloty on Global&#39;s investment in ELCHO.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Other Deductions</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $1 million increase for the quarter ended September 30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was primarily due to foreign currency transaction losses of $1 million on Global&#39;s investment in ELCHO.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $2 million decrease for the nine months ended September 30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, was primarily due to the absence of a loss on early extinguishment of debt of $3 million that was recognized in 2004 offset by a $1 million change in derivative fair values.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Interest Expense</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $1 million and $3 million decrease for the quarter and nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2005, respectively, as compared to the same periods in 2004, was primarily due to the deconsolidation of Dhofar Power.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Income Taxes</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $18 million and $9 million increase for the quarter and nine months ended September 30, 2005, respectively, as compared to the same periods in 2004, was primarily due to the recording of $9 million of U.S. tax associated with repatriation of funds under the American Jobs Creation Act of 2004 and a change in the mix of domestic and international earnings for Global.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Income from Discontinued Operations, including Gain on Disposal, net of tax</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>See Note 3. Discontinued Operations, Dispositions and Acquisitions of the Notes for additional information.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Other</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>To supplement the Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements presented in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the U.S. (GAAP), PSEG and Energy Holdings use the non-GAAP measure of Earnings Before Interest and Taxes (EBIT).</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG&#39;s and Energy Holdings&#39; management each reviews EBIT internally to evaluate performance and manage operations and believes that the inclusion of this non-GAAP financial measure provides consistent and comparable measures to help shareholders understand current and future operating results. PSEG and Energy Holdings urge shareholders to carefully review the GAAP financial information included as part of this Quarterly Report.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Global</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The following table summarizes Global&#39;s capital at risk, net contributions to EBIT and non-recourse interest expense in the following regions as of September&nbsp;30, 2005 and December&nbsp;31, 2004 and for the quarters and nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2005 and 2004.</font></p>
<p align=center>68</p>

<table width=100% cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0><tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(A)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>Total Capital at Risk includes Global&#39;s gross investments and equity commitment guarantees less non-recourse debt at the project level.</font></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(B)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>For investments accounted for under the equity method of accounting, includes Global&#39;s share of net earnings, including Interest Expense and Income Tax Expense.</font></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(C)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>Non-Recourse Interest is Interest Expense on debt that is non-recourse to Global.</font></td></tr>
</table>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Liquidity'>LIQUIDITY AND CAPITAL RESOURCES</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The following discussion of liquidity and capital resources is on a consolidated basis for PSEG, noting the uses and contributions of PSEG&#39;s three direct operating subsidiaries, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Operating Cash Flows</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>For the nine months ended September 30, 2005, PSEG&#39;s operating cash flow decreased by approximately $347 million from $1.3 billion to $907 million, as compared to the same period in 2004, due to net decreases from its subsidiaries as discussed below.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G&#39;s operating cash flow increased approximately $54 million from $410 million to $464 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, primarily due to increased customer deposits received from BGS suppliers offset by higher deferred balances due to significantly increased commodity prices.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power&#39;s operating cash flow decreased approximately $200 million from $488 million to $288 million for the nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, primarily due to increased margin requirements because of significantly increased commodity prices.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Energy Holdings&rsquo; operating cash flow decreased approximately $148 million from $368 million to $220 million for the nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2005, as compared to the same period in 2004, due primarily to the absence of tax benefits and payments associated with the termination of certain leases in 2004.</font></p>
<p align=center>69</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Common Stock Dividends</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Dividend payments on common stock for the quarters ended September&nbsp;30, 2005 and 2004 were $0.56 and $0.55 per share, respectively, and totaled approximately $134 million and $131 million, respectively. Dividend payments on common stock for the nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2005 and 2004 were $1.68 and $1.65 per share, respectively, and totaled approximately $401 million and $391 million, respectively. Future dividends declared will be dependent upon PSEG&rsquo;s future earnings, cash flows, financial requirements, alternative investment opportunities and other factors. On October 18, 2005, PSEG&rsquo; s Board of Directors approved a common stock dividend of $0.56 per share for the third quarter of 2005, reflecting an indicated annual dividend rate of $2.24 per share.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Short-Term Liquidity</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of September&nbsp;30, 2005, PSEG and its subsidiaries had a total of approximately $2.7 billion of committed credit facilities with approximately $1.6 billion of available liquidity under these facilities. In addition, PSEG and PSE&amp;G have access to certain uncommitted credit facilities. As of September&nbsp;30, 2005, there were no loans outstanding under these uncommitted credit facilities for either PSEG or PSE&amp;G.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>All of the credit facilities below have been modified or structured to accommodate the potential merger with Exelon. Each of the facilities is restricted to availability and use to the specific companies as listed below.</font></p>
<table width=100% cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0><tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=center valign=bottom><b><font color=#000000><small>Company<br>

<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=center valign=top colspan=15><b><font color=#000000><small>(Millions)</small></font></b></td></tr>

<div align=left>
<p><font color=#000000><hr color=#000000 noshade align=left width=48 size=0></font></p>
</div>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>(A)&nbsp;Terminated in October 2005.</font></p>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>(B)&nbsp;PSEG/Power co-borrower facility.</font></p>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>(C)&nbsp;These amounts relate to letters of credit outstanding.</font></p>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>(D)&nbsp;Energy Holdings/Global/Resources joint and several co-borrowed facility.</font></p>
<p align=center>70</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG believes it has sufficient liquidity to fund its short-term cash needs. On May&nbsp;31, 2005, PSEG established a new five-year $650 million revolving credit facility that replaced the $280 million credit facility that expired in March 2005 and the $350 million credit facility that was scheduled to expire in December 2005.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On April 29, 2005, PSEG&rsquo;s $75 million bilateral term loan facility and $25 million bilateral revolver facility expired.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G believes it has sufficient liquidity to fund its short-term cash needs. In May 2005, PSE&amp;G entered into a bilateral agreement for a $100 million term loan. PSE&amp;G terminated this agreement in October 2005.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of September&nbsp;30, 2005, Power had loaned $62 million of excess cash to PSEG.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On August 31, 2005, Power&rsquo;s $25 million credit facility expired.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>During the
  nine months ended September 30, 2005, the increase in commodity prices has reduced
  available liquidity as Power was required to post additional margin for sales
  contracts entered into in the normal course of business. Should commodity prices
  continue to rise, additional margin calls may be necessary relative to existing
  power sales contracts. As these contract obligations are fulfilled, liquidity
  requirements are reduced. With the addition of the PSEG and Power joint and
  several facilities listed below, Power believes that it has sufficient liquidity
  to fund its short-term cash needs.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In addition,
  ER&amp;T maintains agreements that require Power, as its guarantor under performance
  guarantees, to satisfy certain creditworthiness standards. Many of these agreements
  allow the counterparty to demand that ER&amp;T provide performance assurance,
  generally in the form of a letter of credit or cash, in the event of a downgrade
  of Power&rsquo;s credit rating to below investment grade. While Power believes
  that a downgrade to below investment grade is unlikely, management believes
  that Power could meet collateral requirements with current credit facilities,
  including the new credit agreements listed below, and its ability to access
  additional sources of liquidity through bank lending and/or capital market transactions.
  See Note&nbsp;5. Commitments and Contingent Liabilities of the Notes for further
  information.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG and Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>In October 2005, PSEG and Power entered into the following credit agreements:</font></p>

<td align=right valign=baseline nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td align=right valign=baseline nowrap><font color=#000000>$</font></td>
<td align=right valign=baseline><font color=#000000>200</font></td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=center valign=baseline nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td align=center valign=baseline><font color=#000000>Letters of Credit</font></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=baseline nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=baseline><p style='margin-left:1em;text-indent:-1em;'></p></td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td></tr>
</table>
<div align=left>
<p><font color=#000000><hr color=#000000 noshade align=left width=48 size=0></font></p>
</div>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>(A)&nbsp;PSEG/Power co-borrower facility</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of September&nbsp;30, 2005, Energy Holdings had loaned $61 million of excess cash to PSEG. In addition, Energy Holdings and its subsidiaries had $256 million in cash, including $192 million invested</font></p>
<p align=center>71</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>offshore. See Note&nbsp;2. Recent Accounting
  Standards of the Notes regarding repatriation of certain portions of these funds
  in October 2005.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On June&nbsp;30, 2005, Energy Holdings entered into a $150 million five-year bank revolving credit agreement. This bank revolving credit agreement replaced a $200 million three-year bank revolving credit agreement that was scheduled to expire in October 2006.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>External Financings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>For the nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2005, PSEG issued approximately 929,000 shares under its Dividend Reinvestment Program and Employee Stock Purchase Plan for approximately $55 million.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On August 8, 2005, the 6.25% trust preferred securities that were issued in November 2002 in connection with PSEG&rsquo;s Participating Units (PEPS) were remarketed. The PEPS consist of a forward purchase contract for PSEG common stock and a trust preferred security. The remarketing reset the coupon on the trust preferred security to 5.381%, which will mature in November 2007. The PEPS investors will use the proceeds from the remarketing as collateral to be used for settling the forward purchase contract on November&nbsp;16, 2005. Upon settlement, PSEG will receive cash proceeds of approximately $460 million and issue 11.4 million shares of common stock assuming its stock price is above $40.248 per share</font><b><font color=#000000>.</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In September
  2005, PSEG issued $375 million of floating rate senior unsecured debt due in
  2008, callable at par after one-year. The proceeds were used to redeem PSEG&rsquo;s
  subordinated debt underlying $225 million of Enterprise Capital Trust I, 7.44%
  Series A and $150 million of Enterprise Capital Trust III, 7.25% Series C Preferred
  Securities in October 2005.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In September 2005, PSE&amp;G Transition Funding II LLC (Transition Funding II) issued approximately $103 million of its Transition Bonds, Series 2005-1, in four classes. Proceeds were used to purchase from PSE&amp;G the rights to collect a transition bond charge from electric customers pursuant to a BPU order. PSE&amp;G used those proceeds to reduce short-term debt.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In July 2005, PSE&amp;G issued $250 million of its 5.25% Secured Medium-Term Notes Series D due 2035. The proceeds were used to redeem $125 million of PSE&amp;G&rsquo;s First and Refunding Mortgage Bonds, 9.125% Series&nbsp;BB due July 2005 and to reduce short-term debt.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>For the nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2005, PSE&amp;G Transition Funding LLC (Transition Funding) repaid approximately $105 million of its transition bonds.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>During 2005, Energy Holdings made cash distributions to PSEG totaling $287 million, including a $100 million return of capital in February 2005, a $184 million preference unit redemption in May 2005 and $3 million of preference unit distributions.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Debt Covenants</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG&rsquo;s, PSE&amp;G&rsquo;s, Power&rsquo;s and Energy Holdings&rsquo; respective credit agreements generally contain customary provisions under which the lenders could refuse to advance loans in the event of a material adverse change in the borrower&rsquo;s business or financial condition.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As explained in detail below, some of these credit agreements also contain maximum debt-to-equity ratios, minimum cash flow tests and other restrictive covenants and conditions to borrowing. Compliance with applicable financial covenants will depend upon the respective future financial position, level of earnings and cash flows of PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings, as to which no assurances can be given. The ratios presented below are for the benefit of the investors of the related</font></p>
<p align=center>72</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>securities to which the covenants apply. They are not intended as a financial performance or liquidity measure. The debt underlying the preferred securities of PSEG, which is presented in Long-Term Debt in accordance with Financial Accounting Standards Board Interpretation No. 46, &ldquo;Consolidation of Variable Interest Entities&rdquo;, is not included as debt when calculating these ratios, as provided for in the various credit agreements. As discussed previously, the rise in commodity prices has increased margin requirements and has resulted in increased Accumulated Other Comprehensive Loss (OCL), which reduces total equity. This has resulted in increases to the debt to capitalization ratios at PSEG and Power. These ratios could be further increased due to additional OCL resulting from the potential need to recognize an additional minimum pension liability
(see Other Comprehensive Loss below), however, PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings expect to continue to meet the financial covenant requirements, discussed below.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Financial covenants contained in PSEG&rsquo;s credit facilities include a ratio of debt (excluding non-recourse project financings, securitization debt and debt underlying preferred securities and including commercial paper and loans, certain letters of credit and similar instruments) to total capitalization (including preferred securities outstanding) covenant. This covenant requires that at the end of any quarterly financial period, such ratio not be more than 70.0%. As of September&nbsp;30, 2005, PSEG&rsquo;s ratio of debt to capitalization (as defined above) was 60.3%.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Financial covenants contained in PSE&amp;G&rsquo;s credit facilities include a ratio of long-term debt (excluding securitization debt and long-term debt maturing within one year) to total capitalization covenant. This covenant requires that at the end of any quarterly financial period, such ratio will not be more than 65.0%. As of September&nbsp;30, 2005, PSE&amp;G&rsquo;s ratio of long-term debt to total capitalization (as defined above) was 48.4%.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In addition, under its First and Refunding Mortgage (Mortgage), PSE&amp;G may issue new First and Refunding Mortgage Bonds against previous additions and improvements, provided that its ratio of earnings to fixed charges calculated in accordance with its Mortgage is at least 2 to 1, and/or against retired Mortgage Bonds. As of September&nbsp;30, 2005, PSE&amp;G&rsquo;s Mortgage coverage ratio was 4.96 to 1 and the Mortgage would permit up to approximately $1.7 billion aggregate principal amount of new Mortgage Bonds to be issued against previous additions and improvements.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG and Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Financial covenants contained in the PSEG/Power joint and several credit facility include a ratio of debt to total capitalization for each specific borrower. This facility has a 70% debt to total capitalization covenant for PSEG (see definition under PSEG financial covenants) and a 65% debt to total capitalization covenant for Power. For the purposes of calculating the Power ratio, debt (including loans, certain letters of credit and similar instruments) to total capitalization, adjusted for the $986 million Basis Adjustment (see Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheets), covenant applies. This covenant requires that at the end of any quarterly financial period, such ratio will not exceed 65.0%. As of September&nbsp;30, 2005, Power&rsquo;s ratio of debt to capitalization (as defined above) was 51.6%.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In April 2003, Energy Holdings issued $350 million of Senior Notes which contain financial covenants that include debt incurrence tests consisting of a debt service coverage test and a ratio of consolidated recourse indebtedness to recourse capitalization test, which covenants require that Energy Holdings will not incur additional consolidated recourse indebtedness, other than certain permitted indebtedness, unless, on a pro forma basis, giving effect to the incurrence of the additional consolidated recourse indebtedness: (i)&nbsp;the debt service coverage ratio would be at least 2 to 1 and (ii)&nbsp;the ratio of consolidated recourse indebtedness to recourse capitalization would not exceed 0.60 to 1. Certain permitted indebtedness, such as permitted refinancings and borrowings, are excluded from the</font></p>
<p align=center>73</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>requirements under this test. The provisions of the Senior Notes also restrict Energy Holdings from selling assets with a net book value greater than 10% of its assets in any four consecutive quarters, unless the proceeds are used to reduce debt of Energy Holdings or its subsidiaries or are retained by Energy Holdings.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Energy Holdings entered into a $150 million five-year bank revolving credit agreement in June 2005 with a covenant requiring the ratio of Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, Depreciation and Amortization (EBITDA) to fixed charges to be greater than 1.75. This bank revolving credit agreement replaced a $200 million three-year bank revolving credit agreement that was entered into in October 2003. As of September&nbsp;30, 2005, Energy Holdings&rsquo; coverage of this covenant was 2.77. Additionally, Energy Holdings must maintain a ratio of net debt to EBITDA of less than 5.25. As of September&nbsp;30, 2005, Energy Holdings&rsquo; ratio under this covenant was 4.02. Energy Holdings is a co-borrower under this facility with Global and Resources, which are joint and several obligors. The terms of the agreement include a pledge of
Energy Holdings&rsquo; membership interest in Global, restrictions on the use of proceeds related to material sales of assets and the satisfaction of certain financial covenants. Net cash proceeds from asset sales in excess of 5% of total assets of Energy Holdings during any 12-month period must be used to repay any outstanding amounts under the credit agreement. Net cash proceeds from asset sales during any 12-month period in excess of 10% of total assets must be retained by Energy Holdings or used to repay the debt of Energy Holdings, Global or Resources.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Credit Ratings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The current ratings of securities of PSEG and its subsidiaries are shown below and reflect the respective views of the rating agencies. Any downward revision or withdrawal may adversely affect the market price of PSEG&rsquo;s, PSE&amp;G&rsquo;s, Power&rsquo;s and Energy Holdings&rsquo; securities and serve to increase those companies&rsquo; cost of capital and limit their access to capital. All ratings have a stable outlook unless otherwise noted. (N) denotes a negative outlook, (P) denotes a positive outlook and (WD) denotes a credit watch developing indicating that ratings could be raised or lowered. There is no assurance that the ratings will continue for any given period of time or that they will not be revised by the rating agencies, if, in their respective judgments, circumstances so warrant. Each rating given by
an agency should be evaluated independently of the other agencies&rsquo; ratings. The ratings should not be construed as an indication to buy, hold or sell any security.</font></p>

<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(A)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>Moody&rsquo;s ratings range from&nbsp;Aaa (highest) to C (lowest) for long-term securities and P-1 (highest) to NP (lowest) for short-term securities.</font></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(B)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>S&amp;P ratings range from&nbsp;AAA (highest) to D (lowest) for long-term securities and A-1 (highest) to D (lowest) for short-term securities.</font></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(C)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>Fitch ratings range from AAA (highest) to D (lowest) for long-term securities and F-1 (highest) to D (lowest) for short-term securities.</font></td></tr>
</table>

<p align=right><i><font color=#000000>&nbsp;</font></i></p>

<p align=center>74</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On December&nbsp;20, 2004, in conjunction with the announcement of the Merger Agreement between PSEG and Exelon, all of the rating agencies reviewed their ratings and took the following actions:</font></p>
<table width=100% cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0><tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td width=24pt align=left valign=top nowrap></td>
<td width=12pt align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>&bull;</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>Moody&#39;s affirmed the ratings for PSEG, Power and Energy Holdings. Moody&#39;s revised its outlook to stable from negative for PSEG and Power. The outlook for PSE&amp;G remained stable and the outlook for Energy Holdings remained negative.</font></td></tr>
<tr>
<td>&nbsp;</td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td width=24pt align=left valign=top nowrap></td>
<td width=12pt align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>&bull;</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>S&amp;P placed its&nbsp;BBB Corporate Credit Rating for PSEG, Power and PSE&amp;G on Credit Watch with developing implications. S&amp;P indicated that, if not for the Merger, the corporate credit ratings assigned to PSEG and its subsidiaries, other than Energy Holdings, would have been lowered to BBB&ndash;with a negative outlook. S&amp;P lowered its outlook for Energy Holdings to negative.</font></td></tr>
<tr>
<td>&nbsp;</td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td width=24pt align=left valign=top nowrap></td>
<td width=12pt align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>&bull;</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>Fitch affirmed its ratings for PSEG, Power, PSE&amp;G and Energy Holdings. Fitch revised the outlook for PSEG and Power to positive from stable. The outlook for PSE&amp;G remained stable and Energy Holdings remained negative.</font></td></tr>
</table>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Other Comprehensive Loss</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>For the nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2005, PSEG, Power and Energy Holdings had an Other Comprehensive Loss/(Gain) of $316 million, $395 million and $(81) million, respectively, due primarily to net unrealized losses on derivatives accounted for as hedges in accordance with Statement of Financial Accounting Standards (SFAS) No. 133, &ldquo;Accounting for Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities&rdquo;, as amended (SFAS 133), unrealized gains and losses in the NDT Funds at Power and foreign currency translation adjustments at Energy Holdings.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>During the nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2005, Power&#39;s OCL has increased from $49 million to $444 million. The primary cause was an increase of approximately $370 million related to the change in market value, net of taxes, of energy and related contracts that qualify for hedge accounting that were previously entered into by Power in the normal course of business. During the nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2005, the increase in gas and electric prices has resulted in unrealized losses on many of those contracts, which are recorded in OCL as a reduction to equity.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color="#000000">Minimum
  Pension Liability</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Due
  to the potential for a lower required discount rate and reduced earnings on
  the pension plan investments through September 30, 2005</font>, PSEG, PSE&amp;G,
  Power and Energy Holdings may be required to record a minimum pension liability
  on their respective Consolidated Balance Sheets as of December 31, 2005. As
  calculated under SFAS No. 87 &#8220;Employers Accounting for Pensions&#8221;,
  a minimum pension liability exists and must be recorded when the accumulated
  benefit obligation (ABO) of the plan exceeds the fair value of the plan assets
  as of its annual measurement date. The minimum pension liability is reduced
  or reversed when funding occurs, or when the fair value of the pension plan
  assets grow to a level above that of the ABO. At this time, PSEG is monitoring
  the fair market value of its investments and its ABO and is evaluating options
  available with respect to this issue. Since PSEG&#39;s measurement date is December&nbsp;31,
  2005, management is unable to predict what the impact could be, however the
  impact could be material to PSEG&#39;s, PSE&amp;G&#39;s, Power&#39;s and Energy
  Holdings&#39; financial position and, more specifically, could result in a decrease
  in equity since a majority of the offset to the minimum pension liability would
  be recorded in OCL.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Capital'>CAPITAL REQUIREMENTS</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>It is expected that the majority of funding for capital requirements of PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings will come from their respective internally generated funds. The balance will be provided by the issuance of debt at the respective subsidiary or project level and, for PSE&amp;G and Power, equity contributions from PSEG. PSEG does not expect to contribute any additional equity to Energy Holdings. Projected construction and investment expenditures approved in the current business plans for PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings are consistent with amounts disclosed in the Annual</font></p>
<p align=center>75</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>Reports on Form&nbsp;10-K of PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2004.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>During the nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2005, PSE&amp;G made approximately $372 million of capital expenditures, primarily for reliability of transmission and distribution systems. The $372 million excludes approximately $25 million spent on cost of removal, net of salvage.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>During the nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2005, Power made approximately $290 million of capital expenditures (excluding $55 million for nuclear fuel), primarily related to the Bethlehem, New York (Albany) site, the Linden station in New Jersey and various other projects at Nuclear and Fossil.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>During the nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2005, Energy Holdings incurred approximately $26 million of capital expenditures, primarily related to capital projects at SAESA, Dhofar Power and Skawina.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Accounting'>ACCOUNTING MATTERS</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>For information related to recent accounting matters, see Note 2. Recent Accounting Standards of the Notes.</font></p>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000><a name='Qualitative'>ITEM 3. QUALITATIVE AND QUANTITATIVE DISCLOSURES<br>
ABOUT MARKET RISK</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The market risk inherent in PSEG&rsquo;s, PSE&amp;G&rsquo;s, Power&rsquo;s and Energy Holdings&rsquo; market risk sensitive instruments and positions is the potential loss arising from adverse changes in foreign currency exchange rates, commodity prices, equity security prices and interest rates as discussed in the Notes to Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements (Notes). It is the policy of each entity to use derivatives to manage risk consistent with its respective business plans and prudent practices. PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings have a Risk Management Committee (RMC) comprised of executive officers who utilize an independent risk oversight function to ensure compliance with corporate policies and prudent risk management practices.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Additionally, PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings are exposed to counterparty credit losses in the event of non-performance or non-payment. PSEG has a credit management process, which is used to assess, monitor and mitigate counterparty exposure for PSEG and its subsidiaries. In the event of non-performance or non-payment by a major counterparty, there may be a material adverse impact on PSEG and its subsidiaries&rsquo; financial condition, results of operations or net cash flows.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Except as discussed below, there were no material changes from the disclosures in the Annual Reports on Form&nbsp;10-K of PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2004 or Quarterly Reports on Form&nbsp;10-Q for the quarters ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 and June&nbsp;30, 2005.</font></p>
<p align=center>76</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Commodity Contracts</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG and Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The availability and price of energy commodities are subject to fluctuations from factors such as weather, environmental policies, changes in supply and demand, state and federal regulatory policies, market rules and other events. To reduce price risk caused by market fluctuations, Power enters into supply contracts and derivative contracts, including forwards, futures, swaps and options with approved counterparties, to hedge its anticipated supply and demand differential. These contracts, in conjunction with demand obligations help optimize the value of owned electric generation capacity.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Normal Operations and Hedging Activities</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power enters into physical contracts, as well as financial contracts, including forwards, futures, swaps and options designed to reduce risk associated with volatile commodity prices. Commodity price risk is associated with market price movements resulting from market generation demand, changes in fuel costs and various other factors.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power&rsquo;s derivative contracts are accounted for under Statement of Financial Accounting Standards (SFAS) No. 133, &ldquo;Accounting for Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities,&rdquo; as amended and interpreted (SFAS 133), its amendments and related guidance. Changes in the fair value of qualifying cash flow hedge transactions are recorded in Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income (OCI), and gains and losses are recognized in earnings when the underlying transaction occurs. Changes in the fair value of derivative contracts that do not meet hedge criteria under SFAS 133 and the ineffective portion of hedge contracts are recognized in earnings currently. Additionally, changes in the fair value attributable to fair value hedges are similarly recognized in earnings.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Many non-trading contracts qualify for the normal purchases and normal sales exemption under SFAS 133 and are accounted for upon settlement.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Trading</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power maintains a strategy of entering into trading positions to optimize the value of its portfolio of generation assets, gas supply contracts and its electric and gas supply obligations. Power engages in physical and financial transactions in the electricity wholesale markets and executes an overall risk management strategy to mitigate the effects of adverse movements in the fuel and electricity markets. In addition, Power has non-asset based trading activities, which have significantly decreased. These contracts also involve financial transactions including swaps, options and futures. These activities are marked to market in accordance with SFAS 133, its amendments and related guidance, with gains and losses recognized in earnings.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Value-at-Risk (VaR) Models</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power uses VaR models to assess the market risk of its commodity businesses. The portfolio VaR model for Power includes its owned generation and physical contracts, as well as fixed price sales requirements, load requirements and financial derivative instruments. VaR represents the potential gains or losses, under normal market conditions, for instruments or portfolios due to changes in market factors, for a specified time period and confidence level. Power estimates VaR across its commodity businesses.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power manages its exposure at the portfolio level. Its portfolio consists of owned generation, load-serving contracts (both gas and electric), fuel supply contracts and energy derivatives designed to manage the risk around the differential between generation and load. While Power manages its risk at the portfolio level, it also monitors separately the risk of its trading activities and its hedges. Non-trading mark-to-market (MTM) VaR consists of MTM derivatives that are economic hedges, some of which qualify for hedge accounting. The MTM derivatives that are not hedges are included in the trading VaR. The trading VaR and Non-Trading MTM VaR are presented in the table below.</font></p>
<p align=center>77</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The VaR models used by Power are variance/covariance models adjusted for the delta of positions with a 95% one-tailed confidence level and a&nbsp;one-day holding period for the MTM trading and non-trading activities and a 95% one-tailed confidence level with a one-week holding period for the portfolio VaR. The models assume no new positions throughout the holding periods, whereas Power actively manages its portfolio.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of September&nbsp;30, 2005 and December&nbsp;31, 2004, trading VaR was approximately $1 million and $2 million, respectively.</font></p>
<table width=100% cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0><tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>

<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Credit Risk</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of September&nbsp;30, 2005, Resources has a remaining gross investment in four leased aircraft of approximately $36 million. On September&nbsp;14, 2005, Delta Airlines (Delta) and Northwest Airlines (Northwest), the lessees for Resources&rsquo; four remaining aircraft, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. Energy Holdings continues to believe that it will be able to fully recover its investments in these aircraft.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Other Supplemental Information Regarding Market Risk</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The following presentation of the activities of Power is included to address the recommended disclosures by the energy industry&rsquo;s Committee of Chief Risk Officers. For additional information, see Note 6. Risk Management of the Notes.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The following table describes the drivers of Power&rsquo;s energy trading and marketing activities and Operating Revenues included in its Condensed Consolidated Statement of Operations for the quarter ended September&nbsp;30, 2005. Normal operations and hedging activities represent the marketing of electricity available from Power&rsquo;s owned or contracted generation sold into the wholesale market. As the information in this table highlights, MTM activities represent a small portion of the total Operating Revenues for Power. Activities accounted for under the accrual method, including normal purchases and sales, account for the majority of the revenue. The MTM activities reported here are those relating to changes in fair value due to external movement in prices.</font></p>
<p align=center>78</p>

<div align=left>
<p><font color=#000000><hr color=#000000 noshade align=left width=48 size=0></font></p>
</div>
<table width=100% cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0><tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(A)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>Includes derivative contracts that Power enters into to hedge anticipated exposures related to its owned and contracted generation supply, all asset-backed transactions and hedging activities, but excludes owned and contracted generation assets.</font></td></tr>
</table>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The following table indicates Power&rsquo;s energy trading assets and liabilities, as well as Power&rsquo;s hedging activity related to asset-backed transactions and derivative instruments that qualify for hedge accounting under SFAS 133, its amendments and related guidance. This table presents amounts segregated by portfolio which are then netted for those counterparties with whom Power has the right to set off and therefore, are not necessarily indicative of amounts presented on the Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheets since balances with many counterparties are subject to offset and are shown net on the Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheets regardless of the portfolio in which they are included.</font></p>
<p align=center>79</p>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Wherever possible, fair values for these contracts were obtained from quoted market sources. For contracts where no quoted market exists, modeling techniques were employed using assumptions reflective of current market rates, yield curves and forward prices as applicable to interpolate certain prices. The effect of using such modeling techniques is not material to Power&rsquo;s financial results.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The following table identifies losses on cash flow hedges that are currently in Accumulated Other Comprehensive Loss (OCL), a separate component of equity. Power uses forward sale and purchase contracts, swaps and firm transmission rights (FTRs) contracts to hedge forecasted energy sales from its generation stations and its contracted supply obligations. Power also enters into swaps, options and futures transactions to hedge the price of fuel to meet its fuel purchase requirements for generation. PSEG, Power and Energy Holdings are subject to the risk of fluctuating interest rates in the normal course of business. PSEG&rsquo;s policy is to manage interest rate risk through the use of fixed-rate debt, floating rate debt and interest rate derivatives. The table also provides an estimate of the losses that are expected to
be reclassified out of OCL and into earnings over the next 12 months.</font></p>
<p align=center>80</p>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Credit Risk</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The following table provides information on Power&rsquo;s credit exposure, net of collateral, as of September&nbsp;30, 2005. Credit exposure is defined as any positive results of netting accounts receivable/accounts payable and the forward value on open positions. It further delineates that exposure by the credit rating of the counterparties and provides guidance on the concentration of credit risk to individual counterparties and an indication of the maturity of a company&rsquo;s credit risk by credit rating of the counterparties.</font></p>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The net exposure listed above, in some cases, will not be the difference between the current exposure and the collateral held. A counterparty may have posted more collateral than the outstanding exposure, in which case there would not be exposure. Net exposure to non-investment grade companies is primarily to coal and other fuel suppliers. Counterparties for whom there is no external rating include privately held companies, foreign entities and municipal utilities. These entities are rated by PSEG using an internal model.</font></p>
<p align=center>81</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000><a name='Controls'>ITEM 4. CONTROLS AND PROCEDURES</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Disclosure Controls and Procedures</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings have established and maintain disclosure controls and procedures which are designed to provide reasonable assurance that material information relating to each company, including their respective consolidated subsidiaries, is made known to the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer of each company by others within those entities. PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings have established a disclosure committee which is made up of several key management employees and which reports directly to the Chief Financial Officer and Chief Executive Officer of each respective company. The committee monitors and evaluates the effectiveness of these disclosure controls and procedures. The Chief Financial Officer and Chief Executive Officer of each company have evaluated the effectiveness
of the disclosure controls and procedures as of September&nbsp;30, 2005 and, based on this evaluation, have concluded that the disclosure controls and procedures were effective in providing reasonable assurance during the period covered in these quarterly reports.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Internal Controls</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>During the third quarter of 2005, PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings each made enhancements to internal controls. These enhancements, which will improve the design and operational effectiveness of control processes for financial reporting, included significant changes to internal controls including enhanced policies and procedures in the wholesale energy transacting processes.</font></p>
<p align=center>82</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">

<p align=center>83</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000><a name='Other'>ITEM 5. OTHER INFORMATION</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Certain information reported under the 2004 Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K and the Quarterly Reports on Form&nbsp;10-Q for the quarters ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 and June&nbsp;30, 2005 are updated below. Additionally, certain information is provided for new matters that have arisen subsequent to the filing of the 2004 Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K and Quarterly Reports on Form&nbsp;10-Q for the quarters ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 and June&nbsp;30, 2005. References are to the related pages on the Form&nbsp;10-K and Forms&nbsp;10-Q as printed and distributed.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Federal Regulation</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>ReliabilityFirst</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On September&nbsp;27, 2005, PSEG submitted an application to join ReliabilityFirst, a reliability organization that is seeking to consolidate certain independent regional reliability councils that currently promote the reliability of the electric system throughout the Mid-Atlantic and Central United States. Pursuant to the Energy Policy Act of 2005, which became law on August&nbsp;8, 2005, FERC now possesses the authority to empower such an organization to propose and enforce reliability standards, and issued a Notice of Proposed Rulemaking in this regard on September&nbsp;15, 2005. When FERC designates ReliabilityFirst as such an Electric Reliability Organization, PSEG may be subject to additional regulation.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Reliability Must-Run (RMR) Status in PJM</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>2004 Form&nbsp;10-K, Page 16, March 31, 2005 Form&nbsp;10-Q, Page 70 and June&nbsp;30, 2005 Form&nbsp;10-Q, Page&nbsp;81.</font></b></i><font color=#000000> Although applicable tariff provisions differ from region to region, RMR tariff provisions provide compensation to a generation owner when a unit proposed for retirement must continue operating for reliability purposes. On February&nbsp;24, 2005, Power requested that the FERC approve such cost-of-service rate treatment for the Sewaren&nbsp;1, 2, 3 and 4 and Hudson 1 units. If approved, the rates would provide approximately $23 million and $17 million of annual revenues for the Sewaren and Hudson units, respectively, plus reimbursements of Power&#39;s expenditures in connection with certain construction at the units that are necessary to maintain reliability, offset
by certain revenues earned in PJM&#39;s energy market.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On April 25, 2005, the FERC issued an order accepting the February&nbsp;24, 2005 filing, subject to refund and hearing, effective February&nbsp;24, 2005, but establishing settlement procedures and a hearing on certain issues. Effective February&nbsp;24, 2005, subject to refund and hearing, Power began to collect a monthly fixed payment of $3.3 million, net of operating margins at the units. On August&nbsp;9, 2005, the parties reached a settlement in principle of the issues that FERC set for hearing. A detailed settlement was filed with FERC on September&nbsp;23, 2005, which will be subject to FERC review. The settlement permits Power to recover annual fixed costs of approximately $19 million and $14.5 million for the Sewaren and Hudson units, respectively, plus reimbursements of Power&#39;s expenditures in connection with
certain construction at the units that are necessary to maintain reliability, offset by certain revenues earned in PJM&#39;s energy market.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Market Power</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>2004 Form&nbsp;10-K, Page 17 and June 30, 2005 Form&nbsp;10-Q, page 82. </font></b></i><font color=#000000>On July&nbsp;5, 2005, FERC issued an order accepting the updated market power analysis that PSEG Lawrenceburg submitted on August&nbsp;30, 2004, as supplemented on February&nbsp;7, 2005 and February&nbsp;15, 2005. FERC&#39;s acceptance allows the Lawrenceburg facility to continue to sell wholesale power at market-based rates. FERC&#39;s order requires Lawrenceburg to file a revised market power analysis within 30 days of the pending merger with Exelon and to treat Exelon as an affiliate for purposes of Exelon&#39;s market-based rate codes of conduct, which are on file with FERC to guard against cross-subsidization between business units. The order also requires Lawrenceburg to file an additional compliance filing
within 30 days of the order</font></p>
<p align=center>84</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>to revise their codes of conduct to state that they cannot sell power to affiliates without first receiving FERC authorization to do so. Lawrenceburg made the required filing on August 2, 2005, and FERC accepted this filing on September 15, 2005.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, and Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>PJM Reliability Pricing Model (RPM)</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On August 31, 2005, PJM filed its RPM with FERC. The RPM constitutes a locational installed capacity market design for the PJM region, including a forward auction for installed capacity priced according to a downward-sloping demand curve and a transitional implementation of the market design. PJM requested that FERC issue an order on the proposal by January 1, 2006 in order to permit implementation of the RPM by June 1, 2006. Comments, interventions and protests of the filing were due to FERC by October 19, 2005. PSE&amp;G and Power filed comments generally supporting the RPM and requesting limited modifications in specific areas. Numerous other parties filed comments and protests. PSEG, PSE&amp;G and Power are unable to predict the outcome of this proceeding.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Settlement of Exelon Corporation (Exelon) v. PPL Electric Utilities Corporation (PPL) et al.</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On September 14, 2005, Exelon and PPL filed with FERC an offer of settlement regarding a dispute that arose in 2004 regarding an error by PJM that incorrectly charged Exelon for transmission congestion charges that PJM should have attributed to PPL. The settlement requires PPL to pay Exelon $33 million and allocates the remaining $8 million to all PJM members. Comments, interventions and protests regarding the settlement were due to FERC by October 4, 2005. Several parties, including PSE&amp;G and Power, protested the settlement, which is currently pending before FERC. PSEG, PSE&amp;G and Power are unable to predict the outcome of this proceeding.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>FERC Order No. 888</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On September 16, 2005, FERC issued a Notice of Inquiry seeking comments on whether reforms are needed to the protections that FERC established in its Order No. 888 in order to prevent undue discrimination and preference in the provision of transmission service. If FERC ultimately adopts structural remedies such as further separating the ownership of generation and transmission, PSEG, PSE&amp;G and Power&#39;s results of operations could be negatively affected.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>PJM Long-Term Transmission Rate Design</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>June 30, 2005 Form&nbsp;10-Q, Page 83. </font></b></i><font color=#000000>On May 31, 2005, FERC issued an order addressing the recovery of costs for transmission upgrades designated through PJM&#39;s Regional Transmission Expansion Plan (RTEP) process. Among other matters, FERC&#39;s order responded to a proposal to continue PJM&#39;s current zonal rate design. FERC concluded that the existing rate design may not be just and reasonable, and established a hearing to examine the justness and reasonableness of continuing PJM&#39;s modified zonal rate design. Under the schedule for this proceeding, which was adopted by the Presiding Administrative Law Judge following a prehearing conference on June 23, 2005, this hearing will commence in April 2006. The May 31, 2005 order also accepts the tariff sheets filed by certain
PJM transmission owners to establish the general procedures for filing to recover the costs incurred under the RTEP process, subject to further compliance filings. In accordance with the schedule for this proceeding, certain entities filed proposals with FERC on September 30, 2005 for alternative rate designs for the PJM region. If FERC adopts one or a combination of these alternatives, PSEG, PSE&amp;G, or Power&#39;s results of operations could be negatively affected. PSEG, PSE&amp;G and Power are unable to predict the outcome of this proceeding.</font></p>
<p align=center>85</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>State Regulation</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Ratepayer Protection</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On August 1, 2005, the BPU initiated a new proceeding to consider whether ratepayer protections are necessary in light of the repeal of Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935, as amended (PUHCA) under the Energy Policy Act of 2005, which became law on August 8, 2005. In its order, the BPU requested information from each New Jersey public utility regarding its financial and organizational structure, and the BPU indicated that it was in the process of preparing a formal rulemaking recommendation to address these issues. On October 7, 2005, the BPU initiated an informal stakeholder process in this proceeding and requested comments from New Jersey&#39;s public utilities regarding the BPU&#39;s access to utility records, limits on utility diversification, restrictions on the transfer of capital by utilities to their corporate
parents or affiliates, affiliate transactions, and the prevention of cross-subsidization. If the BPU ultimately adopts additional ratepayer protections, PSEG&#39;s and PSE&amp;G&#39;s results of operations could be negatively affected. PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings are not able to predict the outcome of this proceeding at this time.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Remediation Adjustment Clause (RAC) Filing</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>2004
  Form&nbsp;10-K, Page 21 and March 31, 2005 Form&nbsp;10-Q, Page 72. </font></b></i><font color=#000000>On
  April 25, 2005, PSE&amp;G filed its&nbsp;RAC-12 filing with the BPU to recover
  approximately $18 million of remediation program expenditures for the period
  from August 1, 2003 through July 31, 2004. PSE&amp;G believes that its expenditures
  for&nbsp;RAC-12 were reasonable and that its current rates should be continued
  to recover the&nbsp;RAC-12 costs. On October 6, 2005 PSE&amp;G signed a settlement
  agreement with the Ratepayer Advocate and the BPU. The settlement agreement,
  which provides for PSE&amp;G to recover substantially all of the $18&nbsp;million
  requested, is now awaiting approval from the Administrative Law Judge (ALJ).
  A BPU order approving the settlement is expected shortly thereafter.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Gas Base Rate Case</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>On September 30, 2005, PSE&amp;G filed a petition with the BPU seeking an overall 3.78% increase in its gas base rates to cover the cost of gas delivery to be effective June 30, 2006.Approximately $55 million of the $132.8 million request is for an increase in book depreciation rates. The balance of the request will cover increased plant investment, higher operating expenses and provide an 11% return on equity. PSE&amp;G&#39;s current gas base rates have been in effect since January 2002.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Environmental Matters</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Carbon Dioxide (CO</font></b><b><font color=#000000><small><sub>2</sub></small></font></b><b><font color=#000000>) Emissions</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>2004 Form&nbsp;10-K, Page 25. </font></b></i><font color=#000000>The environmental and regulatory staff members from the nine states in the Northeast that are participating in the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (RGGI), including New Jersey, New York and Connecticut, issued a proposal in August 2005 that would cap CO</font><font color=#000000><small><sub>2</sub></small></font><font color=#000000> emissions from electric generating units greater than 25 megawatts in the states participating in RGGI. The RGGI proposal also features a multi-state&nbsp;cap-and-trade program with market-based emissions trading. The proposal is currently being evaluated by each of the states&#39; environmental and utility commissions for possible implementation. The Governor of New Jersey, referencing the state&#39;s participation in
RGGI, executed new regulations in October 2005 that designate CO</font><font color=#000000><small><sub>2</sub></small></font><font color=#000000> as an air contaminant potentially subject to regulation. The ultimate outcome of this initiative, and its impact on Power, if any, cannot be determined at this time.</font></p>
<p align=center>86</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
